li.p: The structure of the SH construction
An NSH-like process: the benefactive predicate age-ru

subsection.heading: 1 Introduction
subsection.p: Every language is equipped with some means to make speech polite, less offensive, less assertive, or less direct. 1 One typical way to do so is to employ an interrogative or a subjunctive in place of a command or an imperative sentence. For example, the interrogative (1b) and the subjunctive (1c) are considered to be more polite expressions than the imperative (1a):

(1)
a. Pass me the salt.
b. Will you pass me the salt?
c. Would you pass me the salt?
Similarly, a statement can be made less direct if it is converted to a negative question or a tag question. (2b) and (2c) sound softer and less pushy than (2a):

(2)
a. It is expensive.
b. Isn't it expensive?
c. It is expensive, isn't it?

Another typical way to make speech polite is to designate particular expressions or words as polite versions for certain referents. For example, many European languages have two forms that refer to the second person, and one is considered to be more polite or less intimate than the other. In French, vous is used rather than tu when the speaker feels a need to show some distance from the addressee. Similarly, in polite speech, less direct expressions or euphemisms are preferred to direct ones: pass away for die, bathroom for toilet, etc.

Having observed these cases, polite speech may be characterized in terms of how a certain idea or referent is expressed, and what is at issue is how certain words are used in addition to their original or primary functions. Then polite speech may be considered to be better investigated in the realm of the use of language or pragmatics rather than in that of formal grammar. However, there are languages that exhibit particular grammatical constructions that are productive and primarily just for polite speech. Japanese is such a language and in what follows, I will describe the constructions in Japanese that have to do with honorifics. 2

subsection.heading: 2 Honorific forms in Japanese: overview
subsection.p: For making speech polite, Japanese makes use of the strategies described above as well. That is, questions can be used in place of requests, interrogative forms are considered less direct than straight declaratives, pronouns have several forms which are used differently depending on who they refer to, who the addressee is, and under what sociological situation the utterance is made; particular euphemisms are available for certain expressions, etc. However, what makes the polite speech of Japanese different from these strategies is that it possesses a productive system that is primarily for honorifics. In Japanese grammar, it is widely accepted that Japanese exhibits (at least) three types of honorifics: Performative Honorific (PH) or Hearer Honorific (HH), Subject Honorific (SH), and Object Honorific (OH) or Non-Subject Honorific (NSH). 3 Each honorific type exhibits its own peculiarities, and honorifics are to be considered in terms of the following three conditions; (i) morphological conditions, (ii) grammatical conditions, and (iii) contextual or pragmatic conditions. To illustrate, let us take (3) as an example: 4

(3)
Sato-san-ga Honda-san-ni hon-o kasi-ta.
Sato-Nom Honda-Dat book-Acc lend-Past
‘Sato lent a book to Honda (Sato let Honda borrow a book).’

This sentence has the plain or basic form of the predicate kas(u) ‘lend’. However, the predicate may take any of the three ‘honorific’ forms; V-mas-u, o-V-ni nar-u, and o-V-su-ru, without altering the ‘logical’ meaning, that is, ‘Sato lent a book to Honda (Sato let Honda borrow a book).’ These forms represent the three types of Japanese honorifics:

(4)
a. HH: Sato-san-ga Honda-san-ni hon-o kasi-masi-ta.
Sato-Nom Honda-Dat book-Acc lend-polite-Past
‘Sato lent a book to Honda.’
b. SH: Sato-san-ga Honda-san-ni hon-o o-kasi-ni nat-ta.
Sato-Nom Honda-Dat book-Acc HP-lend-SH-Past
‘Sato lent a book to Honda.’
c. NSH: Sato-san-ga Honda-san-ni hon-o o-kasi-si-ta.
Sato-Nom Honda-Dat book-Acc HP-lend-NSH-Past
‘Sato lent a book to Honda.’

The HH form indicates that the speaker presents her speech in a polite way, being respectful to the hearer or addressee. With the SH form, the speaker elevates the referent of the subject without degrading anyone else including the speaker. NSH, on the other hand, downgrades or demotes the subject, which in effects elevates the referent of a non-subject. Thus, if the speaker utters (4a), she intends to show that she feels it appropriate to express her respect for the addressee, when expressing the logical content of the sentence that is the same as (3). (4b) indicates that the speaker is respectful to the subject of the predicate, Ms./Mr. Sato, while her attitude toward the addressee and the indirect object, Ms./Mr. Honda, is neutral or unspecified. With (4c), on the other hand, the speaker expresses her respect for a non-subject, the indirect object Ms./Mr. Honda in this case, but does not show any particular respect for the addressee or the subject of the sentence. HH and the other honorifics, SH or NSH, are not mutually exclusive and if the speaker considers it appropriate to show her respect for both the addressee and the subject of the sentence, the logical content of (3) is expressed in the form (5a), where the o-V-ni nar(i) part involves the SH marking and the mas(i) part the HH marking. In (5b), the speaker is respectful toward both the addressee, being marked by mas(i), and the (indirect) object of the sentence, which has to do with the o-V-si morphology:

(5)
a. HH & SH: Sato-san-ga Honda-san-ni hon-o o-kasi-ni nari-masi-ta.
b. HH & NSH: Sato-san-ga Honda-san-ni hon-o o-kasi-si-masi-ta.

One may wonder how the speaker expresses her respect for both the subject and the object, which is certainly a possible situation sociologically. However, it is impossible to do so grammatically: one predicate cannot take the SH and NSH forms at the same time. 5 The speaker must put one higher than the other and choose an honorific form accordingly. It seems that when the speaker's respect is to be directed toward both the subject and the object, SH is used, since NSH has the function of making the subject humbler (lower than the object), while SH simply elevates the subject, leaving the status of the object intact (neutral or possibly respectful).
The honorific markings appear not only on verbs, as in (4) and (5), but also on adjectives and on the copulative predicate, as shown in (6–7):

(6)
Adjectives
yasasi-i
‘kind-pres.’
a. Plain: Yamada-san-wa yasasi-i.
‘Yamada is kind.’
b. HH: Yamada-san-wa yasasi-i-des-u.
c. SH: Yamada-san wa o-yasasi-i / o-yasasi-ku-te-irassyar-u.
d. NSH: Does not apply

(7)
Copula
da
‘be-pres.’
a. Plain: Hanako-san-wa sensei da.
‘Hanako is a teacher.’
b. HH: Hanako-san-wa sensei des-u /de gozaimas-u.
c. SH: Hanako-san-wa sensei de irassyar-u.
d. NSH: Does not apply
The basic functions and morphological forms of the three types of honorifics are summarized in (8–10):

(8)
Hearer Honorifics (HH) – respect is due to the addressee:
a. Verbs: The polite predicate mas-u is attached to the connective form of a verb. 6
b. Adjectives: Des-u is attached to the indicative form of an adjective.
c. Copula: The polite form of the copula, des-u or de gozaimas-u, is used instead of the plain da.

(9)
Subject Honorifics (SH) – respect is due to a subject:
a. Verbs: 7
Either (i) or (ii), where (i) is considered to be more polite than (ii):
(i) HP-V-ni nar-u; the sequence of the honorific prefix (HP) (o- or go-), the connective form of a verb, the particle ni, and the predicate nar-u ‘become’. 8
(ii) The form equivalent to the passive morpheme (r)are-ru is attached to a verb stem.
b. Adjectives: 9
An HP is prefixed, as in o-utukusi-i ‘beautiful’. Optionally, the SH suppletive form of the verb ir-u ‘be, exist’ (irassyar-u) attaches to the connective form of an adjective, as in o-utukusiku-te-irassyar-u, which makes the form politer than the one without.
c. Copula: The connective form of the copula (de) is followed by the SH suppletive form of the verb ir-u ‘be, exist’, irassyar-u.

(10)
Non-Subject Honorifics (NSH) – respect is due to a non-subject:
a. Verbs: 10
HP-V su-ru: the sequence of HP, the connective form of a verb, and the predicate su-ru ‘do’ or its suppletive NSH form itas-u.
b. Adjectives: No NSH forms
c. Copula: No NSH forms

The formation of honorifics given above applies only to native words. There is a large number of Sino-Japanese (SJ) predicates that necessarily involve a native predicate to hold a tense morpheme: SJ verbs consist of a verbal noun (VN) and the light verb su-ru ‘do’, as in ryokoo su-ru ‘travel’ and dokusyo su-ru ‘read’, and SJ adjectives are made up of an adjectival noun (AN) and the copula da, as in byooki da ‘be sick’, kirei da ‘beautiful’. 11 Examples follow:

(11)
SJ verbs, e.g., syookai su-ru ‘introduce-Light Verb-Pres.’:
a. HH: Hayasi-san-ga Ito-san-ni Jun-o syookai si-masi-ta.
Hayasi-Nom Ito-Dat Jun-Acc introduce-LV-Polite-Past
‘Hayashi introduced Jun to Ito.’
b. SH: Hayasi-san-ga Ito-san-ni Jun-o go-syookai ni nat-ta.
go-syookai nasat-ta
go-syookai s-are-ta.
introduce-Hon-Past
c. NSH: Hayasi-san-ga Ito-san-ni Jun-o go-syookai si-ta.
go-syookai itasi-ta.
The formation of the SJ honorific forms is summarized in (13) and (14):

(13)
HH:
a. SJ verbs: The same as (8a); i.e., the polite predicate mas-u is attached to the infinitive form of the light verb su-ru, as in si-mas-u.
b. SJ adjectives: The same as (8c); i.e., the copula is converted to the polite form.

(14)
SH:
a. SJ verbs: Either (i), (ii), or (iii), and the hierarchy of the politeness goes (ii) > (i) > (iii):
(i) HP-VN-ni nar-u; basically the same as (9ai), but a VN is used in place of the connective form of the verb.
(ii) HP-VN nasaru: nasaru is the suppletive SH form of the verb su-ru ‘do’.
(iii) HP-VN s-are-ru: basically the same as (9aii) and the passive morphome is attached to the verb su-ru.
b. SJ adjectives: The same as (9c); i.e., the connective form of the copula, de, is followed by the suppletive SH form of the verb ir-u ‘be, exist’, irassyar-u.

Besides predicates, nouns can be prefixed by an HP, as in go-kazoku ‘family’, o-tegami ‘letter’, o-udon ‘Japanese noodles’. These form may mark HH as in (15a), in which o- is attached to the plain form hana ‘flower’, which indicates that the speaker is most probably female, and SH as in (15b), where the respect is paid to the genitive-marked noun Sato-sensei, which serves as the subject of the SJ noun, kooen ‘lecture’: 12

(15)
a. Hanako-ga o-hana-o kat-ta.
Hanako-Nom PH-flower-Acc buy-Past
‘Hanako bought flowers.’
b. Sato-sensei-no go-kooen-ga mamonaku hazimar-u.
Sato-teacher-Gen PH-lecture-Nom soon begin-Pres
‘Professor Sato's lecture will soon begin.’

In the above, I have presented a rather detailed description of the honorific forms, intending to show that honorific processes in Japanese are not just peripheral phenomena but involve various grammatical aspects of Japanese. To properly understand them, lexical, morphological, syntactic, and pragmatic considerations are called for. In what follows, I will mainly discuss SH and NSH, since they involve not only the honorific form of a predicate but the grammatical presence of an item to the referent of which the speaker's respect is due. The occurrence of HH, on the other hand, is triggered by the addressee and does not grammatically affect other items in a sentence, and vice versa. For this reason, I will not discuss HH any further in the following. See Harada (1976) and Ide and McGloin (1990) for relevant discussion on the use of HH.

subsection.heading: 3 Subject Honorification (SH)
subsection.p: As briefly mentioned in the previous section, SH forms are licensed by the subject of the sentence, which clearly indicates that SH is to be described within sentence grammar. Within generative grammatical studies, Harada (1976) proposes an analysis of honorific processes in terms of transformational rules. His rules for SH not only specify under what syntactic condition SH is triggered but also derive the morphological forms described in (9a). In a more recent framework, Toribio (1990) and Ura (1999) present an analysis in terms of feature checking between the subject and the SH form of a predicate. In both approaches, the key to SH is the syntactic presence of a particular type of subject.

subsection.heading: 3.1 The conditions on the subject
subsection.p: As the above description of SH indicates, the SH form is allowed only when the subject refers to a person to whom the speaker's respect is due. Observe the following examples:

(16)
a. Sensei-ga warat-ta.
teacher-Nom laugh-Past
‘The teacher laughed.’
b. Sensei-ga o-warai-ni nat-ta.
teacher-Nom HP-laugh-Hon-Past
‘The teacher laughed (honorific).’
c. {*Watasi-ga/ *Imooto-ga} o-warai-ni natta.
I-Nom sister-Nom HP-laugh-Non-Past
‘{I/My sister} laughed (honorific).’

(17)
a. Sensei-ga gakusei-ni hon-o watasi-ta.
teacher-Nom student-Dat book-Acc pass-Past
‘The teacher passed a book to students.’
b. Sensei-ga gakusei-ni hon-o o-watasi-ni nat-ta.
teacher-Nom student-Dat book-Acc HP-pass-Hon-Past
‘The teacher passed (honorific) a book to students.’
c. *Gakusei-ga sensei-ni hon-o o-watasi-ni nat-ta.
student-Nom teacher-Dat book-Acc HP-pass-Hon-Past
‘The student passed (honorific) a book to the teacher.’

The subject of the (b) sentences is sensei ‘teacher’, who is considered to be looked up to in ordinary social circumstances, and the use of the SH forms is appropriate. The subject of (16c), on the other hand, is the speaker herself or the speaker's family member. Since pragmatic conditions on honorifics involve (18) as a basic rule, (16c) is inappropriate:
(18) The speaker may not pay respect to or show contempt for herself or the members of her in-group. 13
Similarly, (17c) is inappropriate, since gakusei ‘student’ is ordinarily not subject to respect. Note that sensei ‘teacher’ as the object of the sentence does not trigger SH. 14

On the basis of these facts, Harada proposes an analysis where the feature of the subject triggers SH, which involves a set of lexical, morphological, and syntactic transformations that give rise to the forms described in (9) and (14). Details aside, under his analysis, the predicate takes (i.e., is converted into) its SH form, if the subject is an NP that refers to a person “socially superior to the speaker (SSS)” to whom respect is due. He proposes (19) as the first rule of the set of SH transformations: 15

(19)
Subject Honorific Marking:
Mark the predicate as [Subject Honorific] if its subject is an SSS.

Though (19) is a transformational rule, it is clear that Harada considers it a kind of agreement process, triggered by the SSS subject. In a more recent framework, where agreement is considered to be a feature-checking relation between the two items in question, (19) can be restated as in (20):
(20) The SSS feature of the subject NP must be checked by the SSS feature of the predicate.
This is the direction that has recently been pursued by Toribio (1990) and Ura (1999) within the Minimalist framework.

subsection.heading: 3.2 SH as agreement
subsection.p: Toribio (1990) accounts for SH in terms of agreement between specifiers and heads. As will be reviewed in more detail in section 3.3, Toribio analyzes the regular SH form of a predicate – i.e., HP-V-ni nar-u – in the following way: (i) the connective form of a verb, which she considers gerundive, is a nominal whose category is D; (ii) an HP attaches to D, just as ordinary nouns (Ds) undergo HP prefixation (cf. section 2); (iii) -ni is the oblique case assigned by the verb nar-u; (iv) nar-u is a raising verb (see also Suzuki 1989).

Given this morphological analysis of the SH form, the checking of the features relevant to SH proceeds as follows: the subject generated at the Spec of a predicate phrase (equivalent to vP in the sense of Chomsky 1995c) stops at the Spec of gerund DP (and at the Spec of the VP of nar-u) on the way to the Spec of TP and has its SH feature checked against the honorific feature of D, which is specifically marked by the presence of HP. That is, the SH feature is considered as an agreement feature that resides in the subject DP, and it is checked independently of its Case feature. In Toribio's system, the Case feature is checked against T, while the SH feature is checked against D of the gerund. 16

Toribio's analysis is not only plausible but seems essentially on the right track. However, it is necessary to closely examine the mechanisms she seems to assume in more detail before adopting it as the right analysis. For example, she does not provide any direct evidence that shows that the SH feature and the nominative Case feature of the subject are checked independently by different heads or at different sites. That is, as far as the data she presents are concerned, it seems possible to analyze the predicate nar-u with the tense feature as possessing all the relevant features that can check the features of the subject. In Toribio's system, the SH feature is checked at the Spec of gerundive (i.e., connective) D, which is marked by an HP. Thus, if no HP is involved in the SH form, which is possible in some suppletive SH forms, she wrongly predicts that the SH feature of the subject is not checked, or she has to assume that the SH form itself checks the SH feature of the subject. To see this point, observe (21) with suppletive SH predicates, which involve only predicates without an HP:

(21)
a. {Sensei-ga/ *Gakusei-ga} soo ossyat-ta.
teacher-Nom student-Nom so say(Hon)-past
‘{The teacher/The student} said so.’
b. {Sensei-ga/ *Gakusei-ga} Kobe-ni irassyar-u.
teacher-Nom student-Nom Kobe-to go(Hon)-past
‘{The teacher/The student} went to Kobe.’

The SH forms of the verbs iw(u) ‘say’ and ir(u) ‘be, exist’ are not of the expected o-V-ni nar-u form (i.e., *?o-ii-ni nar-u, *o-i-ni nar-u), but the suppletive forms ossyar(u) and irassyar(u), respectively, which cannot be analyzed into a sequence of separate items. That is, in (21), the SH verbs themselves involve the features responsible for checking the features of the subject. It thus seems reasonable to assume that the checking of the relevant features take place all at once at TP, the subject being at the Spec of TP and the verb at the head of T. In order to argue that the SH feature is an agreement feature independent of the Case feature, which Toribio assumes, we need to examine the cases where Case and SH are clearly triggered by different elements. Ura (1999) examines such cases.
The sentences examined so far all involve a subject marked by Nominative ga. However, Japanese also allows Dative subjects. Observe (22):

(22)
a. Sensei-ga eigo-ga {wakar-u/ o-wakari ni nar-u.}
teacher-Nom English-Nom understand-Pres HP-understand-Hon-Pres
‘The teacher understands English.’
b. Sensei-ni eigo-ga {wakar-u/ o-wakari ni nar-u.}
teacher-Dat English-Nom understand-Pres HP-understand-Hon-Pres
‘(the same as (22a))’

Certain stative predicates take a Dative subject, provided that the object is marked Nominative (cf. Kuno 1973c). Dative-marked subjects, just like Nominative-marked subjects, trigger SH, as the examples in (22) show (cf. Harada 1976; Shibatani 1977). It is clear from the examples in (23) that what triggers SH is not a Nominative-marked NP (DP) but the item that serves as a subject, irrespective of whether it is marked Nominative or Dative:

(23)
a. Taro-ga sensei-ga {wakar-u/ *o-wakari ni nar-u.}
Taro-Nom teacher-Nom understand-Pres HP-understand-Hon-Pres
‘Taro understands the teacher.’
b. Taro-ni sensei-ga {wakar-u/ *o-wakari ni nar-u.}
Taro-Dat teacher-Nom understand-Pres HP-understand-Hon-Pres
‘(the same as (23a))’
In (23), the subject is Taro and the object is sensei ‘teacher’. Though sensei, which is SSS in Harada's sense, is marked Nominative, it cannot trigger SH.
To account for this phenomenon, Ura proposes the system described in (24) within the Minimalist framework:

(24)
(i) The EPP-feature (or D-feature) of T is strong.
(ii) The dative subject of the Dative Subject Construction (DSC) is generated at the Spec of VP (more precisely, at the Spec of vP) and assigned the inherent Dative Case -ni, which the stative predicates that exhibit DSC can assign to a DP.
(iii) Agreement (i.e., SH) is independent of Nominative Case.
(iv) T's agreement feature is strong, but its Nominative Case feature is weak.
(v) T's Nominative Case feature can check more than one Nominative Case.

Ura's system assumes the basic mechanisms of the Minimalist program: (24i) guarantees the syntactic presence of a nominal at the Spec of TP. With respect to (22), the phrases sensei-ga in (22a) and sensei-ni in (22b) satisfy this requirement. (24ii) applies only to a Dative subject. The subject sensei occurs at the Spec of VP (rather vP) but can be marked Dative if the predicate is of the type that allows DSC. With other types of predicates, a subject is marked Nominative. Regardless of its Case types, the subject is raised to the Spec of TP to check the EPP feature of T. The subject at the Spec of TP can also check T's agreement feature, which is strong (to be checked before Spell Out). The well-formedness of SH is relevant to this agreement checking. The subject sensei in (22) properly meets the SH feature of the predicate, while Taro in (23) does not. (24iv) and (24v) are necessary assumptions to account for a Nominative object. The Dative subject, being at the Spec of TP, checks T's EPP feature and agreement feature but not T's Case feature. Thus, some DP that is not a subject must be present to check T's Nominative Case feature. The Nominative object DP does it in (22b) and (23b). Furthermore, given (24v), T's Case feature can check the Nominative Case of more than one DP, which accounts for the multiple occurrences of Nominative DPs in (22a) and (23a); the Case features of not only the subject DP but also the object DP are checked by T's Case feature. Thus, to account for the cases of Dative subjects, (24iii) plays a crucial role. Without this assumption, the fact that a Dative subject triggers SH cannot be easily explained.
Another piece of evidence for considering the agreement (or SH) feature independent of the Case feature obtains in tenseless complements with an SH predicate. Observe the following examples:

(25)
a. Sensei-ga sake-o nomi-sugi-ru.
teacher-Nom sake-Acc drink-exceed-Pres
‘The teacher drank sake too much.’
b. Sensei-ga sake-o o-nomi-ni nari-sugi-ru.
teacher-Nom sake-Acc HP-drink-Hon-exceed-Pres
‘(the same as (25a))’

(26)
a. Sensei-ga kankokugo-o hanas-e-ru.
teacher-Nom Korean-Acc speak-can-Pres
‘The teacher can speak Korean.’
b. Sensei-ga kankokugo-o o-hanasi-ni nar-e-ru.
teacher-Nom Korean-Acc HP-speak-Hon-can-Pres
‘(the same as (26a))’

The predicate sugi-ru ‘exceed’ in (25) is a raising predicate and its complement takes the connective form, which presumably does not involve the tense feature. (25b) is derived in the following way: the complement subject sensei-ga checks the SH of the embedded predicate and then moves to the Spec of the matrix T to check its Nominative Case feature. Thus, the Case feature and the SH feature are checked by separate heads. The matrix predicate of (26) is the potential -(rar)e and exhibits the control construction. The predicate of the complement clause is of the root form and its subject is PRO. Whatever Case PRO may assume, it is not Nominative (or PRO may not have any Case), but the SH feature of the embedded predicate should be checked against PRO. Thus, (26) also indicates that the SH feature may be independent of the Nominative Case feature.

Thus, Dative subjects of DSC and tenseless complements of the Raising and Control constructions support the claim that the checking between the subject and the SH-marking on the predicate is done independently of the Case feature, and the feature involved between the two may be some kind of agreement. In Ura's system, it is simply assumed that the SH (or agreement) feature of T, which is inherited from the SH form of the predicate via head-to-head movement, is checked against the subject. Let us now go back to Toribio (and also Suzuki 1989) to examine the structure and morphology of the SH predicate and see exactly what is responsible for checking the SH (or agreement) feature of the predicate.

subsection.heading: 3.3 The structure of the SH construction
subsection.p: Now that it is established that the SH feature checking is independent of the Nominative Case checking, let us see which head is really responsible for SH checking. In section 3.2, we have briefly reviewed Toribio's analysis, in which the SH feature of SH predicates resides in the connective (i.e., ‘gerundive’ in her terms) V with an HP, rather than nar-u, the predicate that actually carries the tense feature. Let us examine this claim more closely.

Both Suzuki (1989) and Toribio (1990) claim that the honorific predicate that has the sequence HP-V-ni nar-u is to be analyzed as having a complex structure where nar-u is a higher predicate, taking a connective verb as its complement. Suzuki presents several arguments for analyzing the HP-V-ni part of the SH form as a ‘gerundive’ nominal.

First of all, as discussed in section 2, an HP attaches not only to the connective form of a verb but also to a noun and an adjective. Assuming that nouns and adjectives in Japanese are categorically [+N], if the connective form of a verb is in fact nominal, i.e., [+N], the HP attachment is generalized: an HP attaches to the head of [+N]. 17 Beside the simplicity in the description of the HP attachment process, the nominal nature of the connective form of the SH predicate is syntactically attested. As described in section 2 ((9a) in particular), the connective form is followed by -ni, which can be analyzed as Dative Case or the connective form of a copula. Whichever it may be, -ni attaches to a nominal category. This is seen in (27):

(27)
a. Sensei-ga sinbun-o o-yomi-ni nat-ta.
teacher-Nom newspaper-Acc HP-read-Hon-past
‘The teacher read (honorific) the newspaper.’
b. *Sensei-ga sinbun-o o-yomi nat-ta.
c. Hanako-ga isya-ni
nat-ta.
Hanako-Nom doctor-NI became
‘Hanako became a doctor.’
d. *Hanako-ga isya nat-ta.
e. Seito-ga sizuka-ni
nat-ta.
Pupil-Nom quiet-NI became
‘The pupils became quiet.’
f. *Seito-ga sizuka nat-ta

The distribution of -ni of the SH form, exemplified in (27a, b), is the same as that of the noun (27c, d) or of the nominal adjective (27e, f). If it is assumed that the category that precedes -ni is a nominal category, the status of -ni being Dative Case seems justifiable. The nominal nature of the connective form is also supported, even if -ni is taken to be a copula. As shown in (28), the copula takes a noun or an adjective, but crucially not a verb:
As compared to the ungrammaticality of (28c), the copula can directly take the SH predicate without -ni or -ni nar-u, as shown in (29): 18

(29)
a. Sensei-ga sinbun-o o-yomi da. (=o-yomi-ni nat-te i-ru)
teacher-Nom newspaper-Acc HP-read copula HP-read-Hon-exist-Pres
‘The teacher is reading the newspaper.’
b. Sensei-ga biiru-o o-nomi da. (=o-nomi-ni nat-te i-ru)
teacher-Nom beer-Acc HP-drink copula HP-drink-Hon-exist-Pres
‘The teacher is drinking beer.’

Sentences in (29) are SH but the meaning of the sequence of the HP-V-copula differs from the HP-V-ni nar-u one. The former is equivalent to that of the HP-V-ni nat-te iru. The presence of -te-ir-u after a V indicates either the progressive aspect, like be V-ing in English, or the perfective aspect, similar to the function of have V-en. If the connective form in (29) is [+N], we can generalize the above fact as follows: the copula takes a [+N] category.

What is of particular interest is that not all the occurrences of the connective form are considered nominal, but only those of the SH predicate (i.e., the connective form with an HP prefixed to it). Thus, replacing (te)-iru with a copula in non-SH expressions gives rise to ungrammatical sentences:

(30)
a. Sensei-ga sinbun-o yon-de-i-ru.
teacher-Nom newspaper-Acc HP-read-Hon-exist-Pres
‘The teacher is reading the newspaper.’
b. *Sensei-ga sinbun-o yomi- da.
teacher-Nom newspaper-Acc read copula

The ungrammaticality of (30b) seems due to the verb status of the connective form here. In short, the connective form can be followed by a copula only when it is nominal. The presence of an HP and -ni and the replaceability of -ni nar-u with a copula are both owing to the nominal nature of the connective form of SH.
Another instance where the connective form of SH behaves differently from other occurrences of the connective form is observed in conjoined sentences, as in (31):

(31)
a. Tanaka-sensei-wa otya-o o-nomi-ni nari, Kato-sensei-wa coffee-o o-nomi-ni nat-ta.
Tanaka-teacher-Top tea-Acc HP-drink-Hon Kato-teacher-Top coffee-Acc HP-drink-Hon-Past
‘Prof. Tanaka drank tea and Prof. Kato drank coffee.’
b. Tanaka-sensei-wa otya-o o-nomi-ni, Kato-sensei-wa coffee-o o-nomi-ni nat-ta.
c. *Tanaka-sensei-wa otya-o o-nomi, Kato-sensei-wa coffee-o o-nomi-ni nat-ta.
d. Tanaka-sensei-wa otya-o nomi, Kato-sensei-wa coffee-o non-da.
drink-past

These are conjoined sentences, and the predicate of the first conjunct is not marked with a tense morpheme. As seen in (31a) and (31d), a typical way to conjoin sentences is to make the verb of the first conjunct into the connective form. SH sentences such as (31b) exhibit another way to conjoin sentences; i.e., delete the nar-u part and end the first conjunct with -ni. Note crucially that the connective form with an HP cannot serve the function of conjoining sentences, as the ungrammaticality of (31c) shows. The behavior of ‘HP-V (connective)’ here (i.e., (31b)) is exactly parallel to nouns and adjectives, as shown in (32) and (33):

(32)
a. Taro-ga sensei-ni nari, Hanako-ga isya-ni nat-ta.
Taro-Nom teacher-Cop become Hanako-Nom doctor-Cop become-past
‘Taro became a teacher and Hanako became a doctor.’
b. Taro-ga sensei-ni, Hanako-ga isya-ni nat-ta.
c. *Taro-ga sensei, Hanako-ga isya-ni nat-ta.

(33)
a. Mati-ga kirei-ni nari, mura-ga benri-ni nat-ta.
town-Nom clean-Cop become village-Nom convenient-Cop become-past
‘The town became clean and the village became convenient.’
b. Mati-ga kirei-ni, mura-ga benri-ni nat-ta.
c. *Mati-ga kirei, mura-ga benri-ni nat-ta.

The generalization seems to be that the [+N] category cannot function as a sentential conjunction. This generalization can be maintained if the HP-V (connective) is considered as [+N], which accounts for the ungrammaticality of (31c) along with that of (32c) and (33c).

Given these facts, Suzuki (1989) analyzes the HP-V part of the SH predicate as a gerundive DP, -ni as Dative Case that is assigned to a gerundive DP, and the predicate nar-u as a higher predicate that takes a gerund as its argument. Toribio's (1990) analysis is essentially the same. 19 Taking it that these two analyses are essentially on the right track, in the following discussion I would like to propose a structure that is a modified version of the two analyses. I consider nar-u a raising predicate rather than a control predicate, adopting Toribio's claim, since the behavior of nar-u in other instances clearly indicates nar-u is a raising verb. 20 As for where the [+N] property of SH verbs lies, I would like to assume that it is at the head of D and what resides at D is an HP. That is, an HP, being a bound morpheme with an agreement feature (i.e., an SSS in the sense of Harada), attracts a verb and forces a DP with SSS to be raised to the Spec of DP. As for the connective form, if the generalization that an HP attaches only to a [+N] category must be maintained, we need to assume that the connective -i morpheme has the category feature [+N]. I leave it open exactly what category it may be: some kind of functional category that selects a VP. Note, however, that the connective form itself is not always a nominal, as the data in (31) suggest, and it can be [+N] or [−N]. We will come back to this issue when we discuss NSH in section 4.
To summarize, sentence (34), for example, is analyzed in the way described in (35):

(34)
a. Sensei-ga sinbun-o o-yomi-ni nat-ta.
teacher-Nom newspaper-Acc HP-read-Hon-past
‘The teacher read the newspaper.’ (honorific)

The main predicate yom- ‘read’ is a transitive and I assume that it has a VP-shell (vP-VP) structure. The vP is a complement of -i, which gives rise to the connective form. As just mentioned, I consider the category of -i to be some kind of functional category (FP), and it has the [+N] feature when used for SH. The FP is a complement of DP whose head is an HP. The HP requires an item with the SSS feature at its Spec. Due to this requirement, the subject of yom-, sensei-ga ‘teacher-Nom’, is attracted and moves to the Spec of DP. As discussed above, -ni may be analyzed as Dative Case, assigned by nar-u ‘become’. However, in (35) I take it as a copula. Nar-u takes a copula phrase (CopP). The subject, whose Agreement feature (SSS) has checked off at the Spec of DP, finally moves to the Spec of TP to have its Case feature checked. As for the Accusative Case of the object, following the general practice, it is covertly checked off by the Accusative Case feature of v.

subsection.heading: 3.4 On honorific prefixes
subsection.p: In the previous section, an HP of the SH form is analyzed as a kind of agreement feature, which attracts the connective form of a verb to its head and a DP. This analysis of an HP is not merely motivated by SH-verbs but supported by honorific or polite forms of nouns and nominal adjectives. As briefly stated in section 2, an HP attaches to a noun as in o-heya ‘room’, go-hon ‘book’, go-syumi ‘hobby’, o-kao ‘face’, o-karada ‘body, health condition’, o-kuruma ‘car’. The presence of an HP makes speech polite in the sense of HH and is used more often in female speech. It has another function when its occurrence is related to honorifics, SH and NSH; that is, the referent of the noun with an HP is made specific and identifiable in the sense that the possessor of the referent is taken to be a target of the speaker's respect. Note that nouns without an HP can be definite or indefinite, specific or non-specific, depending on given contexts. 21 Thus, in the context of (36), the noun hon ‘book’ most probably refers to an indefinite, non-specific book:

(36)
Hanako-ga hon-o kat-ta.
Hanako-Nom book-Acc buy-Past
‘Hanako bought a book.’

Nouns with an HP, however, often refer to specific items which can be identified in a given discourse. In (37a) and (37b), the meanings change depending on whether the HP go- is attached to hon ‘book’. Without the HP go-, hon would refer to any book, but with go-, it would most probably refer to the one that the teacher wrote or owns (i.e., the teacher's book). 22 Because of this function of an HP, the use of go-hon in (37c) and (37d) sounds somewhat funny, since people do not usually return their own books to the library or borrow them from it: 23

(37)
a. Sensei-ga hisyo-ni (go)-hon-o o-watasi-ni nat-ta.
teacher-Nom secretary-Dat HP-book-Acc HP-pass-Hon-Past
‘The teacher passed (his) book to the secretary.’
b. Sensei-ga (go)-hon-o o-sagasi-ni nat-te i-ru.
teacher-Nom HP-book-Acc HP-search-Hon-Prog-Pre
‘The teacher is looking for (his) book.’
c. *?Sensei-ga tosyokan-ni go-hon-o o-kaesi-ni nat-ta.
teacher-Nom library-to HP-book-Acc HP-return-Hon-Past
‘The teacher returned his book to the library.’
d. *?Sensei-ga tosyokan-de go-hon-o o-kari-ni nat-ta.
teacher-Nom library-at HP-book-Acc HP-borrow-Hon-Past
‘The teacher borrowed his book from the library.’
If an HP is in fact a head D and has a definite (and/or specific) feature, this fact naturally follows.

This function of an HP seen in nouns is carried over to the use of an HP in the SH form. That is, the presence of an HP in the SH construction indicates that the event that is described by an SH predicate refers not to any indefinite event but to a definite/specific one. The event must be identifiable, and only a particular individual is to be predicated of the SH predicate. That is, an SH predicate is an open predicate that must be closed by the subject with SSS. The presence of an HP in the SH predicate guarantees this. It is pragmatically natural (and perhaps mandatory) that those that carry the SSS feature are to be identifiable individuals or classes in a given context. Perhaps due to this, the sentences in (38), where the subject is non-specific and indefinite, are not quite felicitous: 24

(38)
a. ?*Misiranu hito-ga hon-o o-kai-ni nat-ta.
stranger-Nom book-Acc HP-buy-Hon-Past
‘The stranger bought (his) book.’
b. ?*Dareka-ga o-warai-ni-natta.
teacher-Nom HP-laugh-Hon-Past
‘Someone laughed.’
The definite/specific nature of HPs is distinctively observed in the following examples:

(39)
a. Watasi-ga o-heya-o soozi si-ta.
I-Nom HP-room-Acc clean-Past
‘I cleaned {SSS's/*my} room.’
b. O-kuruma-ga koware-ta.
HP-car-Nom HP-break-Hon-Past
‘{SSS's/*my} car got broken.’
c. Go-syumi-wa sakanaturi des-u.
HP-hobby-Top fishing-Cop-Pres
‘{SSS's/*my} favorite pastime is fishing.’

(40)
a. Zisin-ni-tuite-no go-kenkyuu-ga syoo-o uke-ta.
earthquake-about-Gen HP-research-Nom prize-Acc receive-Past
‘{SSS's/*my} research on earthquakes received a prize.’
b. Asia-e-no go-ryokoo-ga kizi-ni nat-ta.
Asia-to-Gen HP-trip-Nom article-Cop become-past
‘{SSS's/*my} travel to Asia was put in an article.’
c. Go-seityoo-ga tanosimi da.
HP-growth-Nom pleasure Cop
‘We are looking forward to {SSS's/*my} (process of) growing up.’

In (39), the possessors of the common nouns are not expressed; however, with the presence of an HP, they are to be SSSs and not those owned by the speaker (or her in-group members) or someone who is not worthy of respect. Similarly, the actor/undergoer of the actions/processes expressed in (40) is to be an SSS. Note that if these nouns are used without an HP, the possessor/actor/undergoer can be anyone including the speaker or someone in the speaker's in-group. Thus, it is clear that an HP has the function of making the head noun specific and identifiable, demanding some kind of agreement.

The analysis provided for the SH construction in terms of an HP is applicable to nominals. That is, an HP is a head of D, which takes an NP as its complement, and requires an item with SSS to be at the Spec of D, so that the SSS feature of D is checked off through Spec–Head agreement with the item in Spec. The HP agreement in DPs is illustrated in (41), where pro (null pronominal cagetory) is tentatively posited at the Spec of D, which carries the feature [SSS]:

subsection.heading: 3.5.1 Honorific passives
subsection.p: The SH process discussed above is with the morphological form of HP-V-ni nar-u (i.e., (9ai)) and it is described as a process of agreement between a subject and a DP-head which is an HP. However, as briefly touched upon in (9aii), there is another type of SH that makes use of the passive morpheme -(r)are. Some examples are given in (42):

(42)
a. {Sensei-ga/ *watasi-ga} hon-o kaw-are-ta.
teacher-Nom I-Nom book-Acc buy-Pass-Past
‘{The teacher/I} bought a book.’
b. {Sensei-ga/ *watasi-ga} kodomo-o sikar-are-ta.
teacher-Nom I-Nom child-Acc scold-Pass-Past
‘{The teacher/I} scolded the child.’
c. {Sensei-ga/ *watasi-ga} taore-rare-ta.
teacher-Nom I-Nom fall-Pass-Past
‘{The teacher/I} fell down/ill.’

As the grammaticality contrast between sensei ‘teacher’ and watasi ‘I’ on the subject shows, the presence of -(r)are is allowed only with an SSS subject, the same condition as for SH with the form of HP-V-ni nar-u. To distinguish these two types of SH, let us call them Rare-SH and Naru-SH, respectively.

Given the facts in (42), it may be natural to account for Rare-SH along similar lines to those for Naru-SH. That is, -(r)are is taken as some kind of predicate that requires an SSS subject. To ensure it, let -(r)are have the SSS feature which is to be checked off by an item with the same feature via Spec-Head agreement. This is done if a subject with the SSS feature moves into the Spec of -(r)are on the way to TP-Spec, where its Nominative Case feature is checked off. In this analysis, the derivation of (42a) proceeds as described in (43):

This accounts for the fact that Rare-SH requires an SSS subject; however, this analysis cannot explain why the predicate -(r)are is used for both passives and SH. The analysis (43) suggests that it is a mere coincidence that -(r)are is used for both SH and passives.

Hasegawa (1988), on the other hand, claims that -(r)are in passives and -(r)are in SH are essentially the same predicate. Before presenting her analysis of Rare-SH, let us briefly review how she accounts for passives. In her system, the passive morpheme (including -en in English) is a predicate that takes a VP complement. The category of this predicate may be [+N], as in the case of English -en, or [−N], which is the case of -(r)are in Japanese. The [+N] passive predicate requires Case and absorbs (or is Case-assigned by) the (object) Case feature of the complement predicate. This is done when the complement predicate head-moves to the passive predicate. This gives rise to the typical passive construction, where Object Case is not assigned to the logical object, and the logical object is raised to subject position to receive Nominative Case. The derivation is shown in (44), where an English passive is exemplified: 25

(44)
a. The student was scolded by the teacher.
b.

It is well known that Japanese exhibits (at least) two types of passives; one is called the direct passive, basically equivalent to typical passives like passives in English, and the other is called the indirect passive, where the logical object, if there is one, is marked with Object Case as in actives, but the extra argument shows up as the affectee or experiencer of the event expressed by the complement VP. Observe the examples given in (45):

(45)
a. Sensei-ga kodomo-o sikat-ta.
teacher-Nom child-Acc scold-Past
‘The teacher scolded the child.’
b. Kodomo-ga sensei-ni sikar-are-ta.
child-Nom teacher-Dat scold-Pass-Past
‘The child was scolded by the teacher.’
c. Taro-ga sensei-ni kodomo-o sikar-are-ta.
Taro-Nom teacher-Dat child-Acc scold-Pass-Past
‘Taro got his child scolded by the teacher.’
(45a) is an active sentence, (45b) is a direct passive, and (45c) an indirect passive. Hasegawa's system, which accounts for these passives, is summarized in (46): 26

(46)
a. -(R)are is [−N] and may or may not absorb Case.
b. -(R)are can be either a two-place predicate, requiring an experiencer subject and a complement VP, or a one-place predicate, without a subject.
c. Direct passives obtain when -(r)are is a one-place predicate and absorbs Case.
d. Indirect passives result when -(r)are is a two-place predicate and does not absorb Case.

The direct passive, the case of (46c), is basically the same as the passive of English illustrated in (44). The indirect passive, the case of (46d), is described in (47), which illustrates the derivation of (45c):
(47) [TP Taroi-ga [VP1 ti [VP2 sensei-ni kodomo-o sikar]-(r)are] ta.]

The experiencer Taro is the subject of -(r)are and raised to TP-Spec to receive Nominative Case. The object of the complement verb receives Object Case just like the object of the active counterpart. The complement subject, sensei, receives -ni, which is a sort of default case given to an argument DP that receives neither Nominative nor Objective Case. 27 This accounts for both direct and indirect passives. 28

Given (46a) and (46b), there must be two other possible cases to be examined besides (46c) and (46d), however: (i) -(r)are is a one-place predicate and does not absorb Case, and (ii) -(r)are is a two-place predicate and absorbs Case. Case (ii) can be ruled out easily; the object of the complement ends up not receiving any Case; Nominative Case is given to the matrix subject and Object Case absorbed by -(r)are. What is relevant to the present discussion is case (i). If -(r)are does not absorb the Object Case of the complement verb, a complement object should be able to receive Object Case, as in (47), while the subject of the complement moves to the Spec of the matrix TP to receive Nominative Case. What this gives rise to is (42b), repeated here as (48). This is in fact the case of SH with -(r)are:

(48)
a. Sensei-ga kodomo-o sikar-are-ta.
teacher-Nom child-Acc scold-Pass-Past
‘The teacher scolded the child.’
b. [TP Senseii-ga [VP1 ti [VP2 ti kodomo-o sikar]-(r)are] ta.]
Thus, in Hasegawa's system, Rare-SH is a kind of passive, which she calls honorific passive, and is derived as a natural consequence of her analysis of passives.

What is not accounted for in Hasegawa's analysis is the agreement between the subject and -(r)are. If -(r)are in SH is the same as the one in passives, why does only the former require a particular type of subject, namely an SSS subject? Note that the subjects of direct and indirect passives do not have to be SSS. There seem to be two ways to go about this. One is rather ad hoc but assumes that the intransitive -(r)are that does not absorb Case is marked SSS, which is essentially the same as saying that -(r)are in Rare-SH is an honorific verb different from the passive -(r)are: there is no explanation of why the same morpho-phonological form of -(r)are is used in SH and in passives. The other, which Hasegawa suggests, is to consider the SSS condition on the subject of Rare-SH to be a matter of language use and not a matter of formal grammar. That is, the basic function of -(r)are as a one-place predicate is to quantify an event so as to conceal or make vague the agentivity of the event; a function similar to modals or predicates like seem, likely, etc. In the case of the direct passive, the object becomes the subject, and the agenthood of the logical subject is set in the background of the event in question. In the case of the honorific passive (Rare-SH), the logical subject remains as a subject, receiving Nominative Case. Pragmatically, however, the subject becomes a target of respect with the presence of -(r)are, which has a function of presenting the event as if the referent of the subject was put in the situation where she (involuntarily) ends up acting in a certain way or under-going certain changes. It is considered in Japanese that presenting an activity or event as a natural occurrence is more polite and respectful to the referent of the subject than doing so as a willful act of the subject, as many traditional Japanese grammarians maintain (cf. Tokieda 1941; Ohno 1966; Hashimoto 1969; Kikuchi 1994). Note that the one-place -(r)are that gives rise to Rare-SH is a raising predicate just like nar-u ‘become’, which appears in Naru-SH. If this view is in fact on the right track, what is common in Rare-SH and Naru-SH is the presence of a raising predicate but not the process of agreement, which is possible only when an HP is present.

A piece of indirect evidence that supports the view that -(r)are does not necessarily require a subject with SSS is seen in another use of -(r)are: the one-place -(r)are takes place in the so-called zihatu ‘voluntary, spontaneous, circumstantial’ mood, which is considered to be the original use of -(r)are among traditional grammarians: 29

(49)
a. (Watasi-ni-wa) sore-ga kuyam-are-ru.
I-to-Top it-Nom regret-Pass-Past
‘I regret it./The given circumstances make me regret it.’
b. (Sensei-(ni)-wa) doo omow-are-masu-ka.
teacher-to-Top how think-Pass-Polite-Past
‘How do you think, Professor?’

In this construction, the subject of the complement verb is usually marked by -ni (rather than -ga) and the presence of -(r)are indicates, as the gloss suggests, that the subject cannot help but end up feeling or thinking in a certain way or that given circumstances put the referent of the subject in a particular feeling/ thinking mood. The predicates that can appear in this construction are confined to feeling/thinking verbs. If such verbs are used with -(r)are and take an SSS subject, it is not clear if it is to be taken as an instance of the SH construction or of the voluntary construction. This seems to suggest that the interpretation or function of -(r)are is not lexically or grammatically fixed but that its syntactic structure is uniform regardless of how it function is interpreted. Whether a certain occurrence of -(r)are functions as passive, SH, or voluntary mood depends on the context. Therefore, it seems reasonable to conclude that no formal process of agreement is involved in Rare-SH. 30

subsection.heading: 3.5.2 The yagar-u construction
subsection.p: As opposed to honorifics, there is a construction where an agreement process similar to SH is observed between the subject and the predicate, but the relevant feature is not SSS or honorific but the opposite of it; something like contempt, disgust, or repugnance. Observe (50): 31

(50)
a. {Aitu-ga/ *ano kata-ga/ *ore-ga} kane-o nusumi-yagat-ta.
he(Vul)-Nom that person(Hon)-Nom I(Vul)-Nom money-Acc steal-Vul-Past
‘{He/That person/I} stole money.’
b. {Aitu-ga/ *ano kata-ga/ *ore-ga} kaeri-yagat-ta.
he(Vul)-Nom that person(Hon)-Nom I(Vul)-Nom leave-Vul-Past
‘{He/That person/I} went back home.’
c. {Aitu-ga/ *ano kata-ga/ *ore-ga} kaze-de taore-yagat-ta.
he(Vul)-Nom that person(Hon)-Nom I(Vul)-Nom cold-with fall-Vul-Past
‘{He/That person/I} came down with a cold.’

In (50), both aitu and ano kata refer to a third person individual but they differ in vulgar/honorific features: aitu with the feature of vulgarity and repugnance vs. ano kata with SSS. When the predicate is followed by yagar-u, the item with SSS or the first person, even in its vulgar form like ore, cannot be a subject. Pragmatically and sociologically speaking, the use of the predicate yagar-u is limited and disfavored, since this expression is considered vulgar, offensive, and ill-mannered. For example, it is extremely rare for a woman to use it and it is never used in formal situations. However much suppressed the use of yagar-u may be, its morphological and syntactic conditions are clear and rigid: yagar-u attaches to the connective form of a verb and requires the syntactic presence of someone/something toward which the speaker feels disgust or repugnance. Thus, it may appear to be appropriate to capture this process in a way similar to SH, but the relevant feature is not SSS but repugnance (RPG for short).

As for SH, we have observed two types: Naru-SH and Rare-SH. The former is analyzed in terms of agreement between the subject and the head of a gerundive DP, an HP. As for the latter, as I suggested just above, the requirement on the SSS subject, though it is possible to analyze it in terms of agreement as shown in (43), is not syntactic but pragmatic in nature. Let us see which type yagar-u is to be analyzed as. If it is like Naru-SH, it involves a syntactic agreement. That is, (50a) can be analyzed in a way like (51), where the relevant feature is RPG, not SSS:

(51)
[TP Aitui-ga [VP1 ti
[VP2 ti
hon-o nusumi] -yagat] ta]
[RPG]
[RPG]

Here, yagar-u is analyzed as a raising predicate that takes a VP complement. The complement subject passes through the Spec of yagar-u on its way to Spec of TP. If yagar-u in fact requires agreement with the subject with RPG process, it can check the feature of the subject when the subject stops at the Spec of yagar-u. This analysis is plausible; however, the existence of the following types of sentences suggests that what is at issue is not agreement between the subject and yagar-u, but what semantic or pragmatic function yagar-u has in relation to its complement VP:

(52)
a. Ame-ga furi-dasi-yagat-ta.
rain-Nom fall-start-Vul-Past
‘Rain started to fall down (vulgar). (It started to rain.)’
b. Kuruma-ga koware-yagat-ta.
car-Nom break-Vul-Past
‘The car broke down (vulgar).’

In (52), the subject is inanimate and the complement predicate is unaccusative. What the speaker expresses with yagar-u in these examples is contempt or repugnance not toward the subject but rather toward the entire event expressed by the complement. That is, what (52a) expresses is the speaker's repugnance toward the fact that it started to rain, but not toward the rain itself. The same explanation applies to the examples in (50): what the speaker is disgusted about is not just the subject but the entire event. If so, the syntax of yagar-u is more like Rare-SH (cf. (47)): there is no syntactic agreement between yagar-u and the subject, and what yagar-u does is to quantify or modify the event expressed by a complement VP toward which the speaker feels repugnance. Note in passing that if the event is agentive, the yagar-u construction may appear to express the speaker's repugnance toward the subject rather than the entire event, as observed in examples like (50). This is due to the pragmatic fact that the responsibility of the occurrence of an agentive event would most probably fall on an agentive subject, which gives rise to the interpretation that the subject is a target of the speaker's repugnance. That is, though the yagar-u construction itself does not require a particular subject, unlike SH, as long as agentive events are concerned, it appears that yagar-u agrees with the subject. To conclude, however much yagar-u, Rare-SH, and SH look similar to each other with respect to the fact they all (often) involve particular types of subjects, only SH involves syntactic agreement between the predicate and the subject; the other two processes, yagar-u and Rare-SH, merely involve predicates, yagar-u and rare, that qualify over events expressed by their complement VPs.

subsection.heading: 3.6 On the optionality of agreement
subsection.p: The above discussion has been developed under the assumption that SH is a syntactic agreement process. Namai (2000), however, argues against considering SH as syntactic agreement, claiming that some characteristics of SH do not go along with what syntactic agreement should exhibit. That is, typical syntactic agreement, such as subject–verb agreement in European languages, takes place in a one-to-one fashion without exception as long as structural conditions are met. SH in Japanese, on the other hand, seems to take place optionally, sometimes involving more than one item and sometimes not being triggered. He provides the following examples:

(53)
a. Sensei-ga go-seisiki-ni o-yame-ni nat-ta.
teacher-Nom HP-officially HP-resign-Hon-Past
‘The teacher officially resigned.’
b. [A sensei to B sensei]-ga [otagai-ga kyoogisita koto]-o o-mitome-ni nat-ta.
and -Nom each other-Nom discuss fact-Acc HP-admit-Hon-Past
‘Teacher A and Teacher B admitted that they (each other) discussed.’
c. C sensei-ga wakaku-te o-utukusi-i.
teacher-Nom young-and HP-beautiful-Pres
‘Teacher C is young and beautiful.’
d. C sensei-ga o-wakaku-te utukusi-i.
e. C sensei-ga o-wakaku-te o-utukusi-i.
f. Sensei-ga o-zyoobu/*o-yuumei/yuumei da.
teacher-Nom HP-tough/HP-famous/famous Copula
‘The teacher is tough/famous.’
g. Sensei-ga o-katai/*o-tadasii/tadasii.
teacher-Nom HP-strict/HP-right/right
‘The teacher is strict/right.’

Let us first consider (53b) and (53c–e), which seem to indicate that SH is optional. In (53b), the subject of the complement predicate and that of the matrix predicate refer to the same individual, but only the matrix predicate appears in the form of SH. Similarly in (53c–e), the conjoined predicates, which refer to the same subject, can be in the form of SH, but need not be so. These facts seem peculiar, as Namai argues, if the honorific process is an agreement process triggered by the presence of an SSS subject: how come the same item sometimes triggers honorifics and other times does not? This criticism does not apply to the analysis presented above, however. What triggers is not an SSS item but the presence of D, whose head is HP. Under this view, the process is not optional but mandatory whenever an HP is present. That is, the SH predicate requires the presence of an SSS item that checks off its SSS feature, but not the other way around: an SSS subject does not require the presence of an SH predicate. Hence, (53b) and (53c–e) do not pose any problem.

Similarly, (53f, g) are not problematic to the proposed analysis, either. All there is to be said is that not all adjectives or nominal adjectives take an HP and consequently SH cannot be formed with adjectives that do not allow an HP. If a predicate has no honorific form, no honorification is observed.

The problem that (53a) raises is concerned with the fact that the SSS subject agrees both with the predicate and with the adverb: how can a single subject agree with more than one item? The fact in (53a) is basically the same as the fact in (54), where both the predicate and the object are in the honorific form, referring to the SSS subject:

(54)
Sensei-ga gakusei-ni go-hon-o o-kasi-ni nat-ta.
teacher-Nom student-Dat HP-book-Acc HP-lend-Hon-Past
‘The teacher lent her/his book to the student.’

As discussed in section 3.4, the honorific form of a noun is a DP whose head is an HP, which is checked by the possessor of the noun. The possessor may be a phonologically null pronominal (pro) which may be controlled by the subject of the sentence. If so, the subject sensei in (54), which agrees with the predicate, does not syntactically agree with the object but merely controls the null pronominal that resides at the possessor position of the object. This analysis of (54) can apply to the adverb in (53a). Suppose that the adverb, which is an adverbial form of a nominal adjective, is headed by D, which is an HP. The HP requires a phonologically null item at its Spec, which is controlled by the subject of the sentence.

Thus, all the arguments that Namai presents against considering honorification as syntactic agreement do not apply to the proposed analysis, where honorification is considered not as a process that is triggered by an SSS nominal, but as a process through which the honorific form of a predicate (or rather an HP head of the DP which is a part of the honorific predicate) demands agreement. The proposed analysis can maintain that agreement is one-to-one and mandatory, as long as the predicate in question is of the honorific form. What may need to be considered is what triggers the presence of the honorific form to begin with. We will speculate on it in section 5.2 below.

subsection.heading: 4 Non-Subject Honorification (NSH)
subsection.p: As briefly touched upon in section 2, when the speaker wants to express her respect for the referent of a non-subject, the verb appears in the NSH form, which is HP-V(connective)+su-ru (or HP-V(connective)+ita-su, with the NSH form of su-ru in place of su-ru). Some examples follow:

(55)
a. Hanako-ga sensei-o o-yobi si-ta.
Hanako-Nom teacher-Acc HP-call do-Past
‘Hanako called the teacher.’
b. Taro-ga sensei-o o-tasuke si-ta.
Taro-Nom teacher-Acc HP-help do-Past
‘Taro helped the teacher.’
c. Hanako-ga sensei-ni go-yotei-o o-kiki si-ta.
Hanako-Nom teacher-Dat HP-schedule-Acc HP-ask do-Past
‘Hanako asked the teacher about his/her schedule.’
d. Taro-ga sensei-ni hon-o o-kaesi si-ta.
Taro-Nom teacher-Dat book-Acc HP-return do-Past
‘Taro returned the book to the teacher.’

The relevant feature that triggers NSH is the same as SH, namely SSS, and sensei ‘teacher’, which is the object in (55a) and (55b) and the indirect object in (55c) and (55d), is considered to be marked with this feature. The verb form for NSH and the one for SH are quite similar; i.e., both have an HP and the connective form of the verb. Thus, it may appear that the only difference between SH and NSH is what triggers this particular verb form: the subject for SH and the object for NSH. However, there are some crucial differences between the two honorifics.

subsection.heading: 4.1 Characteristics of NSH
subsection.p: Let us examine the characteristics of NSH in relation to SH. The first and obvious difference between NSH and SH has to do with predicate forms: the honorific form of the predicate, the sequence of an HP and the connective form of the verb, is followed by su-ru ‘do’ in the case of NSH, whereas it is followed by -ni nar-u ‘become’ in SH. We will discuss the function of su-ru, in contrast to nar-u, in section 4.2.1.

Second, as noted by Harada (1976), the occurrence of NSH is conditioned not only by the presence of SSS but also by predicate types. That is, NSH is allowed only when the predicate is agentive (i.e., when the subject serves as an agent role). Compare SH and NSH below:

(56)
a. Sato-sensei-ga/ni gakusei-ga o-wakari-ni nar-u.
Stato-teacher-Nom/Dat student-Nom HP-understand-Hon-Pres
‘Prof. Sato understands the students.’
b. *Gakusei-ga/ni Sato-seisei-ga o-wakari su-ru.
student-Nom/Dat Sato-teacher-Nom HP-understand do-Pres
‘The students understand Prof. Sato.’

(56) has the predicate wakar-u ‘understand’, whose subject is not an agent (probably an experiencer). The grammaticality of (54a) shows that the non-agentive subject Sato-sensei triggers SH, while the same referent when used as an object cannot make a well-formed NSH. Recall that adjectives do not have NSH forms but SH forms (cf. the contrast between SH in (57a)/(58a) and NSH in (57b)/(58b)), and this is due to this condition. Adjectives are not agentive predicates:

(57)
a. Sato-sensei-{ga/ni} obake-ga o-kowa-i
o-kowakute irassyar-u.
Sato-teacher-Nom/Dat ghost-Nom HP-afraid-Hon-Pres
‘Prof. Sato is afraid of ghosts.’
b. *Gakusei-{ga/ni} Sato-sensei-ga o-kowa-i
student-Nom/Dat Sato-teacher-Nom HP-afraid-Pres
‘Students are afraid of Prof. Sato.’

(58)
a. Sato-sensei-ga gakuseitati-ga o-suki da.
o-suki de-irassyar-u.
Sato-teacher-Nom students-Nom HP-like-Copula-Hon-Pres
‘Prof. Sato is fond of the students.’
b. *Gakuseitati-ga Sato-sensei-ga o-suki da.
student-Nom Sato-teacher-Nom HP-like-Pres
‘Students are fond of Prof. Sato.’

Third, the trigger of NSH is not limited to an (indirect) object. As seen in (59), the possessor of the (indirect) object gives rise to NSH. Note that the possessor of the subject cannot trigger SH. Compare (59) and (60): 32

(59)
a. Kyoko-ga sensei-no-(o)-kaban-o o-moti-si-ta.
Kyoko-Nom teacher-Gen-HP-bag-Acc HP-hold-do-Past
‘Kyoko held the teacher's bag (for her/him).’
b. Taro-ga sensei-no-(o)-kata-o o-momi-si-ta.
Taro-Nom teacher-Gen-HP-shoulder-Acc HP-massage-do-Past
‘Taro massaged the teacher's shoulders (for her/him).’
c. Hanako-ga sensei-no-o-taku-ni hana-o o-todoke-si-ta.
Hanako-Nom teacher-Gen-HP-house-to flower-Acc HP-deliver-do-Past
‘Hanako delivered flowers to the teacher's house.’

(60)
a. *Sensei-no-(o)-kaban-ga o-koware-ni nat-ta.
teacher-Gen-HP-bag-Nom HP-break-Hon-Past
‘The teacher's bag got broken.’
b. *Sensei-no-(o)-kata-ga o-kori-ni nat-ta.
teacher-Gen-HP-shoulder-Nom HP-stiff-Hon-Past
‘The teacher's shoulders got stiff.’
c. *Sensei-no-o-taku-ga o-yake-ni nat-ta.
teacher-Gen-HP-house-Nom HP-burn-Hon-Past
‘The teacher's house got burnt down.’

The mere presence of the SSS possessor of the (indirect) object is not enough for NSH to take place, however. As will be seen in section 4.3, there must be some beneficial effects observable on the side of the SSS referent. Compare (59), which is grammatical, with ungrammatical (61):

(61)
a. ?*Kyoko-ga sensei-no-(o)-kuruma-o o-tukai-si-ta.
Kyoko-Nom teacher-Gen-HP-car-Acc HP-use-do-Past
‘Kyoko used the teacher's car (for her/him).’
b. ?*Gakusei-ga sensei-no-(go)-hon-o o-yomi-si-ta.
student-Nom teacher-Gen-HP-book-Acc HP-read-do-Past
‘The students read the teacher's book (for her/him).’

To carry a bag is an act favorable to the possessor of the bag, but to use her car or read her book may not necessarily be a beneficial act for its owner (or designer/author). Thus, the key to the well-formedness of NSH is, as Matsumoto (1997) extensively discusses, benefactivity on (or ‘benefit transfer’ to, in her terms) the referent to whom the speaker's respect is due, which results from the described event. The same point can be made by the following examples, where NSH is observed but no obvious SSS item seems present:

(62)
a. Kyoko-ga syasin-o o-tori-si-ta.
Kyoko-Nom photo-Acc HP-take-do-Past
‘Kyoko took a picture (for SSS).’
b. Hanako-ga biiru-o o-nomi-si-ta.
student-Nom beer-Acc HP-drink-do-Past
‘Hanako drank beer (for SSS).’

The acceptability of (62) depends on whether the activity expressed by the NSH form is beneficial to an SSS, which is implicit in the given context. That is, (62a) is acceptable, if Taro took the SSS's portrait or if Taro's act of taking a picture is of benefit to the SSS. Similarly, (62b) is appropriate, if the beer Hanako drank is the SSS's beer and her drinking it is considered to be of benefit to the SSS. 33 If we assume that the NSH form indicates that there should be an agreement process, we expect there to be an item with SSS syntactically present somewhere in a structure, as a null possessor of the (indirect) object or a null beneficiary argument. In what follows, we will defend such an analysis.

A piece of evidence that suggests that NSH is sensitive to syntactic structure is seen in a fact that Harada (1976) points out. Observe (63), modified from Harada's example (67). Syookai-su-ru ‘introduce’ is a three-place predicate and requires both an object and an indirect object, both of which are possible candidates for a trigger of NSH. If NSH simply requires the pragmatic presence of an SSS, we may expect there to be ambiguity in (63). This prediction is not borne out, however:

(63)
a. Hanako-ga Yamada-san-ni Sato-san-o go-syookai-si-ta.
Hanako-Nom Yamada-Dat Sato-Acc HP-introduce-do-past
‘Hanako introduced Sato to Yamada.’
b. *Taro-ga otooto-ni Yamada-sensei-o go-syookai-si-ta.
Taro-Nom brother-Dat Yamada-teacher-Acc HP-introduce-do-past
‘Taro introduced Prof. Yamada to his younger brother.’
c. Taro-ga Yamada-sensei-ni otooto-o go-syookai-si-ta.
Taro-Nom Yamada-teacher-Dat brother-Acc HP-introduce-do-past
‘Taro introduced his younger brother to Prof. Yamada.’

In (63a), the speaker has respect for Yamada, the indirect object, not for Sato, the direct object. This difference is more clearly seen in the contrast between (63b) and (63c): the speaker's close relative is not subject to the speaker's respect and cannot be an indirect object when the predicate is of the NSH form. The fact in (63) suggests that there should be a structural condition on the choice of a relevant SSS, to which we will turn in section 4.2.
The following summarizes the characteristics of NSH observed in the above:

(64)
a. NSH is triggered by an item with SSS.
b. The NSH involves su-ru ‘do’, not ni-nar-u ‘become’, which is used for SH.
c. The NSH is possible only with a predicate that has an agentive subject.
d. A trigger of NSH is either a direct object, an indirect object, a possessor of an (indirect) object, or an implied beneficiary.
e. NSH is possible only when the event expressed by the NSH predicate favorably affects its trigger; i.e., the trigger must be the beneficiary of the event.
f. When both a direct object and an indirect object are SSS, no ambiguity is observed, but an indirect object wins out and is considered to be the beneficiary.

subsection.heading: 4.2 An analysis of NSH
subsection.p: Given (64), in particular the fact that NSH is sensitive to SSS and involves an HP, which SH also exhibits, it seems plausible to consider NSH as some kind of agreement process just like SH, HP-V-ni nar-u. Harada's (1976) analysis is along this line and is presented in (65): 34

(65)
Harada's Object Honorific marking:
Mark the predicate as [Object Honorific] when an SSS is included in (a) the indirect object, if the predicate is ditransitive, or (b) the direct object, if the predicate is transitive. (Harada 1976: 530)

In Harada's system, since there was no principled way to express (64f) in the given framework (i.e., Standard Theory), the rule (or agreement process) is disjunctively stated. In a more recent framework, Toribio (1990) attempts to account for (64f) in terms of a condition on the distance of movements, assuming that an indirect object resides structurally higher than a direct object.

Toribio's analysis for NSH is essentially the same as her analysis for SH, except that the higher predicate that takes an NSH predicate is a control verb, namely su-ru ‘do’, not a raising verb nar-u ‘become’, which SH makes use of. That is, the honorific part (i.e., HP-V(connective)) is a DP and D attracts an item with SSS. When both an object and an indirect object exist, as in ditransitives, the higher one, the indirect object, moves to the Spec of D. According to this analysis, sentence (63c) is derived in a way shown in (66). Compare this with the derivation of SH, namely (35): 35

Toribio's analysis, presented here, seems to work; however, some discussion is called for concerning the predicate su-ru, the categorical status of the honorific part of the predicate (i.e., HP-V(connective)), and a possessor of an (in)direct object.

subsection.heading: 4.2.1 Su-ru in NSH
subsection.p: As stated in (64b), NSH involves su-ru ‘do’, not nar-u ‘become’, which SH employs, but the honorific part (i.e., HP-V(connective)) is the same for both SH and NSH. It is thus natural to consider that the difference between su-ru and nar-u is responsible for the functional difference between SH and NSH. Su-ru and nar-u are not used exclusively for honorifics but have their independent uses; they function as main verbs. Typical uses of su-ru and nar-u as main verbs are exemplified in (67) and (68), respectively:

(67)
a. Taro-ga tenisu-o. su-ru.
Taro-Nom tennis-Acc do-Pres
‘Taro plays tennis.’
b. Gakusei-ga syukudai-o su-ru.
student-Nom homework-Acc do-Past
‘The students did their homework.’

(68)
a. Ha-ga akaku nat-ta.
leaf-Nom red become-Past
‘The leaves turned red.’
b. Hanako-ga isya-ni nar-u.
Hanako-Nom doctor-Cop become-Pres
‘Hanako will become a doctor.’

Su-ru and nar-u as independent predicates can be analyzed in a way similar to ‘do’ and ‘become’ in English, respectively. That is, su-ru is transitive and requires an agentive subject, while nar-u is a raising predicate. This difference between su-ru and nar-u as an independent predicate is reflected in the honorific structures, as seen in (35) for SH and (66) for NSH: for SH, which uses nar-u, the raising structure is posited and for NSH, which uses su-ru, the control structure is assumed and the subject is agentive.

The functional difference between SH and NSH is due to this structural difference between su-ru and nar-u. That is, SH expresses the speaker's respect toward the subject of the predicate, and it does not matter whether the subject initiates an action or simply undergoes changes. No condition is placed on the subject, which is characteristic of the raising predicate nar-u.

NSH, on the other hand, involves su-ru ‘do’. Though we have been calling NSH ‘honorific’, the function of NSH is not really to indicate respect for the referent of the SSS item, but rather to present the subject (the one who affects the SSS) and her action in a humble way. As mentioned in note 3, section 2, NSH is called the ‘humble form’ in traditional Japanese grammar. That is, by presenting the subject in a humble way, it relatively elevates someone who is affected by the subject's action. Thus, the subject in NSH is considered to be responsible for the occurrence of the event, which explains why NSH is possible only with activity predicates. In terms of structure, the subject of su-ru in NSH is an agent, initiator, or controller of the event expressed by the NSH predicate.

The characterization of su-ru in contrast to nar-u mentioned above suggests that su-ru in NSH is essentially the same as the transitive su-ru exemplified in (67). However, there is one crucial difference between su-ru in NSH and the main verb su-ru in (67). As is clear from the above examples, su-ru in (67) takes a DP marked by Accusative o, whereas what precedes su-ru in NSH does not take any Case marker. If a DP must be Case marked, the fact that the honorific predicate is not followed by a Case marker requires some explanation.
In section 3.3, referring to Suzuki (1989), we have seen that the honorific part of the predicate, HP-V(connective), is a DP. The evidence for its DP (or nominal) status includes (69):

(69)
a. It is prefixed by an HP, which is a D head.
b. It is followed by -ni, which may be a Case marker (or postposition) or the connective form of the copula, da (cf. (27)).
c. It can be followed by the copula, da/des-u (cf. (28–30)).
d. It cannot end the first conjunct in the conjoined structure (cf. (31–33)).
In short, it is only nominals ([+N] categories) that can be preceded by an HP and followed by a Case marker (postposition) or a copula. And nominals cannot end the first conjunct.

If the honorific part of NSH is also nominal, it is expected to behave in a similar way. However, as is clear from the above examples, the honorific part of NSH never appears before -ni (or any case marker or a copula); hence, (69b) and (69c) do not apply to NSH. Let us see if criterion (69d) is relevant. Observe (70):

(70)
a. Hanako-ga Sato-san-o miokuri, Taro-ga Kida-san-o demukae-ta.
Hanako-Nom Sato-Acc see-off Taro-Nom Kida-Acc meet-Past
‘Hanako saw Sato off and Taro went to meet Kida.’
b. Hanako-ga Sato-sensei-o o-miokuri-si, Taro-ga Kida-sensei-o o-demukae-si-ta.
Hanako-Nom Sato-teacher-Acc HP-see-off-do Taro-Nom Kida-teacher-Acc HP-meet-do-Past
‘Hanako saw Prof. Sato off and Taro went to meet Prof. Kida.’
c. *Hanako-ga Sato-sensei-o o-miokuri, Taro-ga Kida-sensei-o o-demukae-si-ta.
Hanako-Nom Sato-teacher-Acc HP-see-off Taro-Nom Kida-teacher-Acc HP-meet-do-Past
‘Hanako saw Prof. Sato off and Taro went to meet Prof. Kida.’

(70a), which is a simple conjoined sentence with the plain verb form, does not involve NSH, and the first conjunct ends with the connective form of the predicate. When the NSH form is used, as shown in (70b) and (70c), the honorific form alone cannot end the first conjunct, even though it is in the connective form. The presence of si- (the connective form of su-ru) is needed to end the first conjunct. Thus, if (69d) is a characteristic of [+N] categories, the honorific part of NSH is most probably [+N].

In view of the behavior of su-ru, however, the nominal status of the honorific part of NSH is not quite obvious. As mentioned above and also in section 2, su-ru can be used not only as a main verb, as exemplified in (67), but also as a light verb, which often appears with an SJ nominal (cf. (11)). Observe the following examples, (71) with the main verb su-ru and (72) with the light verb su-ru:

(71)
a. Hanako-ga {syukudai-o su-ru./ ?*syukudai su-ru.}
Hanako-Nom homework-Acc do-Pres homework-do-Pres
‘Hanako will do her homework.’
b. Kyoko-ga {eigo-no benkyoo-o su-ru./ *eigo-no benkyoo su-ru.}
Kyoko-Nom English-Gen-study-Acc do-Pres English-Gen-study do-Pres
‘Kyoko studies English.’

(72)
a. Syorui-ga {hunsitu si-ta/ *hunsitu-o si-ta.}
document-Nom disappear-do-Past disappearance-Acc do-Past
‘The document got lost.’
b. Kyoko-ga {eigo-o benkyoo su-ru./ *eigo-o benkyoo-o su-ru.}
Kyoko-Nom English-Nom study-do-Pres English-Acc study do-Pres
‘Kyoko studies English.’

The main verb su-ru is a transitive predicate, taking an agentive subject and a theme object that is marked by Object Case o. The light verb su-ru, on the other hand, takes place with an expression that represents an action or change of state (e.g., an SJ nominal), which is crucially not marked by the Object Case o; i.e., the light verb su-ru itself does not have a Case-assigning property, unlike the main verb su-ru.

Taking into consideration these facts about the two types of su-ru, su-ru in honorifics seems to behave ambiguously between the main verb su-ru and the light verb su-ru. It is like the main verb su-ru in that it requires an agentive subject, but it is like the light verb su-ru in that the NSH form of the predicate that precedes su-ru is not (Accusative) Case-marked. As for the behavior in the conjoined structure, NSH is similar to the case of the light verb su-ru construction, to the extent that the connective form of su-ru is required in the first conjunct, as observed in the grammatical contrast between (73) and (74):

(73)
a. Kyoko-ga eigo-no benkyoo-o si,
Kyoko-Nom English-Gen-study-Acc do
Taro-ga kankokugo-no kenkyuu-o su-ru.
Taro-Nom Korean-Gen-research-Acc do-Pres
‘Kyoko studies English and Taro researches Korean.’
b. Kyoko-ga eigo-no benkyoo-o, Taro-ga
Kyoko-Nom English-Gen-study-Acc Taro-Nom
kankokugo-no kenkyuu-o su-ru.
Korean-Gen-research-Acc do-Pres
‘(the same as (73a))’

(74)
a. Kyoko-ga eigo-o benkyoo-si, Taro-ga kankokugo-o kenkyuu su-ru.
Kyoko-Nom English-Acc study-do Taro-Nom Korean-Acc research-do-Pres
‘(the same as (73a))’
b. *Kyoko-ga eigo-o benkyoo, Taro-ga kankokugo-o kenkyuu su-ru.
Kyoko-Nom English-Acc study Taro-Nom Korean-Acc research-do-Pres
‘(the same as (73a))’

It is clear that the Accusative Case-marked item with the main verb su-ru is a DP, but the categorical status of what precedes the light verb su-ru remains controversial. It is analyzed as verbal in Hasegawa (1991), as nominal in Terada (1990), and as category-neutral (verbal noun) in Kageyama (1993) (cf. also Grimshaw and Mester 1988). The exact analysis of the honorific part (HP-V(connective)) of NSH seems to depend on how su-ru is analyzed or whether su-ru in NSH is a main verb or a light verb, or of yet a different kind. It is beyond the scope of this chapter to discuss su-ru further, however. See also Miyamoto (1997) and Takahashi (2000).

In short, the honorific part of NSH behaves differently from that of SH, which is clearly nominal. It does not positively exhibit the nominal characteristics listed in (69), but there is not enough evidence that indicates otherwise, either.

subsection.heading: 4.2.2 Possessor ascension
subsection.p: Toribio does not discuss the case of NSH triggered by a possessor of an (in)direct object and it is not clear from her analysis, which is illustrated in (66), how such a case is accounted for. If NSH is in fact an agreement process, the possessor must somehow be detached from the (in)direct object DP and raised to the Spec of DP whose head is an HP. That is, there must be a process of possessor ascension involved in the NSH of this type.
Possessor ascension, as a matter of fact, is widely observed in Japanese. See the following examples:

(75)
a. Sengetu Hanako-no
musuko-ga kekkon-si-ta.
last month Hanako-Gen son-Nom marry-do-past
‘Hanako's son got married last month.’
b. *Hanako-no
Sengetu musuko-ga kekkon-si-ta.
Hanako-Gen last month son-Nom marry-do-past
c. Hanako-ga
(Sengetu) musuko-ga kekkon-si-ta.
Hanako-Nom last month son-Nom marry-do-past
‘(the same as (75a))’

(76)
a. Taro-ga nakanaka tyuugokugo-no
tango-ga oboer-are-na-i.
Taro-Nom easily Chinese-Gen word-Nom memorize-can-not-Pres
‘Taro cannot memorize Chinese words easily.’
b. *Taro-ga tyuugokugo-no
nakanaka tango-ga oboer-are-na-i.
Taro-Nom Chinese-Gen easily word-Nom memorize-can-not-Pres
c. Taro-ga tyuugokugo-ga
(nakanaka) tango-ga oboer-are-na-i.
Taro-Nom Chinese-Nom easily word-Nom memorize-can-not-Pres
‘(the same as (76a))’

The possessor of the subject in (75a) and that of the object in (76a) can be detached from the head noun and receive -ga, as in the (c) examples above. Note that the head noun and its possessor cannot be separated by a sentential adverb, such as sengetu ‘last month’ or nakanaka ‘easily’, if the possessor is marked Genitive no, which indicates that the possessor and the head noun form a constituent, while they can be separated if the possessor is marked Nominative ga.
