This fact can be described in terms of possessor ascension; namely, when a possessor overtly moves out of a DP, it receives a sentential structural Case, Nominative ga. 36

If we assume that possessor ascension takes place not only overtly but also covertly, the NSH triggered by the possessor of an (in)direct object can be accounted for: the possessor (or its SSS feature) is raised to the Spec of the DP whose head is an HP. A possible problem with this analysis is that SH would never be triggered by the possessor of a subject, as the following sentences show (see also (60)):

(77)
a. Sensei-no
o-kuruma-ga koware-ta.
teacher-Gen HP-car-Nom break-down-past
‘The teacher's car broke down.’
b. Sensei-ga
o-kuruma-ga koware-ta.
teacher-Nom HP-car-Nom break-down-past
‘It is the teacher whose car broke down.’
c. *Sensei-no
o-kuruma-ga o-koware-ni nat-ta.
teacher-Gen HP-car-Nom HP-break-down-Hon-past
d. *Sensei-ga
o-kuruma-ga o-koware-ni nat-ta.
teacher-Nom HP-car-Nom HP-break-down-Hon-past

Regardless of whether possessor ascension occurs overtly or covertly, sensei, the possessor of the car, cannot trigger SH. This remains a problem as long as SH and NSH are considered essentially the same agreement process. We have to leave this problem open.

subsection.heading: 4.3 An NSH-like process: the benefactive predicate age-ru
subsection.p: In the above, we have observed that NSH is possible only when the referent of the SSS, (the possessor of) the (in)direct object, is affected in a favorable way, or is to be taken as the beneficiary of the event. If non-favorable effects are expected on the possessor of the (in)direct object, NSH is not allowed. Relevant examples are given below:

(78)
a. Gakusei-ga Yamada-sensei-o uttae-ta.
student-Nom Yamada-teacher-Acc sue-Past
‘The student sued Prof. Yamada.’
b. *Gakusei-ga Yamada-sensei-o o-uttae-si-ta.
student-Nom Yamada-teacher-Acc HP-sue-do-Past

(79)
a. Gakusei-ga Tanaka-sensei-o party-ni sasot-ta.
student-Nom Tanaka-teacher-Acc party-to invite-Past
‘The students invited Prof. Tanaka to the party.’
b. Gakusei-ga Tanaka-sensei-o party-ni o-sasoi-si-ta.
student-Nom Tanaka-teacher-Acc party-to HP-invite-do-Past

(80)
a. Kyoko-ga sensei-no kuruma-o nusun-da.
Kyoko-Nom teacher-Gen-car-Acc steal-Past
‘Kyoko stole the teacher's car.’
b. *Kyoko-ga sensei-no (o)-kuruma-o o-nusumi-si-ta.
Kyoko-Nom teacher-Gen-HP-car-Acc HP-sue-do-Past

(81)
a. Kyoko-ga sensei-no kaban-o mot-ta.
Kyoko-Nom teacher-Gen-bag-Acc hold-Past
‘Kyoko held the teacher's bag.’
b. Kyoko-ga sensei-no (o)-kaban-o o-moti-si-ta.
Kyoko-Nom teacher-Gen-HP-bag-Acc HP-hold-do-Past

In (78–79), the SSS is the object, but NSH in (78) is inappropriate. Similarly in (80–81), the possessor of the object is SSS, but of the two (b) examples here, only (81b) is allowed. The difference in grammaticality (or acceptability) seems to relate to how favorable the action is to the SSS object. ‘Suing’ or ‘stealing’ is not beneficial to the one who is sued or whose property is stolen, and NSH is not appropriate in such situations. This fact suggests that the structural presence of an SSS is not enough to trigger NSH. One way to deal with this problem is leave it to the realm of how NSH is used, maintaining that syntax allows NSH to be triggered freely in non-beneficial situations such as (78) and (80) but the pragmatic condition regarding beneficial transfer rules them out. This may well be a correct way to consider the above contrast, and in fact Matsumoto (1997) advocates such a direction.

In the following, however, I would like to explore a more syntactically oriented possibility. Let me first point out that there is a construction in Japanese which behaves similarly to NSH; i.e., both express beneficial effects on the (in)direct object (or someone in the context). Observe (82):

(82)
a. Hanako-ga Taro-o tasukete age-ta.
Hanako-Nom Taro-Acc help-give-past
‘Hanako helped Taro.’
b. Hanako-ga Taro-ni syasin-o misete age-ta.
Hanako-Nom Taro-Dat photo-Acc show-give-past
‘Hanako showed Taro the photo.’
c. Hanako-ga Taro-no-kaban-o motte age-ta.
Hanako-Nom Taro-Gen-bag-Acc hold-give-past
‘Hanako held Taro's bag (for him).’

The sentences in (82) do not involve NSH, but the presence of the predicate age-ru in addition to the main predicate indicates that the action is done in favor of the object in (82a), the indirect object in (82b), and the possessor of the object in (82c), characteristics shared by NSH. 37,38 When beneficial effects are not expected on these constituents, the use of age-ru is inappropriate, just like the case of NSH observed in (78b) and (80b): 39

(83)
a. *Hanako-ga Taro-o uttaete age-ta.
Hanako-Nom Taro-Acc sue give-Past
‘Hanako sued Taro (for him).’
b. *Hanako-ga Taro-no kuruma-o nusunde age-ta.
Hanako-Nom Taro-Gen-car-Acc steal-give-past
‘Hanako stole Taro's car (for him).’

The similarity of NSH and the age-ru construction is striking, and it seems desirable that this similarity should be captured. So let us assume that the two constructions involve the same structure. That is, NSH always involves age-ru or its null counterpart. Let us suppose that age-ru (or its null counterpart) is a predicate that takes a VP complement and obligatorily assigns a beneficiary role to the item that moves into its Spec. The predicate of the VP may be of the NSH o-V-su form, which gives rise to the NSH construction, or of the basic form, which renders sentences like (82). This approach predicts that the NSH and age-ru should be able to co-occur, and this prediction is borne out, as seen in (84), where age-ru in its suppletive NSH form, sasiage-ru, takes its place with the NSH complement: 40

(84)
a. Gakusei-ga sensei-o o-tasuke si(te sasiage)-ta.
student-Nom teacher-Acc HP-help-do-give-Past
‘The student helped the teacher.’
b. Hanako-ga sensei-ni syasin-o o-mise si(te sasiage)-ta.
Hanako-Nom teacher-Dat photo-Acc HP-show-do-give-past
‘Hanako showed the photo to the teacher.’
c. Hanako-ga sensei-no-(o)-kaban-o o-moti-si(te sasiage)-ta.
Hanako-Nom teacher-Gen-HP-bag-Acc HP-hold-do-give-past
‘Hanako held the teacher's bag.’

Irrespective of whether sasiage-ru is present, the meaning and function of the sentences remain basically the same. This state of affairs can be explained along the lines suggested above. Suppose that the benefactive predicate age-ru has two NSH forms, sasiage-ru and its phonologically null counterpart, and the NSH o-V-su form always requires the presence of the NSH benefactive predicate (or to put it the other way around, the complement VP of the NSH benefactive predicate, sasiage-ru or its null counterpart, must be of the NSH o-V-su form). Then, regardless of whether sasiage-ru is present, the two versions of (84) are considered to be equally NSH examples, and (84) without sasiage-ru (an instance of ordinary NSH) in fact involves the null counterpart of sasiage-ru in the structure. What is crucial here is that the two forms of NSH in (84), either with sasiage-ru or without it, both involve the same syntactic structure. 41 Then the requirement of beneficial effects on the SSS, which may be an (in)direct object, its possessor, or someone identifiable in the context, can be subsumed under the requirement on the item checked by the benefactive predicate, age-ru, sasiage-ru, or the phonologically null counterpart of sasiage-ru. The benefactive predicate, irrespective of its form, requires a beneficiary item in its Spec. The beneficiary item may be raised from inside the complement VP or may be directly generated at its Spec independently of the VP. When it is raised from inside the complement VP, we obtain sentences where a syntactic argument (or its possessor) appears as a beneficiary. If it is directly generated (or merged) at the Spec of the benefactive predicate, the beneficiary is interpreted as being someone in the context. Since the beneficiary itself can be phonetically null in Japanese, just as any argument identifiable in discourse may (cf. note 38), we obtain NSH (and the age-ru construction) where no obvious beneficiary item is present. In this way, we can maintain that NSH always involves an SSS item that is syntactically present. 42

subsection.heading: 5.1 Honorifics and pro-drop
subsection.p: The descriptions and analyses of honorific phenomena presented above are basically along the lines of Harada's (1976) proposal. In particular, it is his insight that SH and NSH are viewed as agreement processes, and we have so far been concerned mainly with how agreement processes are accounted for, mainly referring to Toribio (1990) and Suzuki (1989). There is another interesting phenomenon that seems to have to do with the agreement of SH and NSH, namely, pro-drop.

In the linguistic literature, the phenomena of pro-drop or null arguments have been captured in two ways: licensed (i) by agreement (Chomsky 1981; Rizzi 1982a) or (ii) by (null) topic (Huang 1984; Hasegawa 1984). 43 Japanese has been considered as the latter type, and Huang and Hasegawa analyze null arguments (e) in (85) as variables bound by null topics:

(85)
a. Taro-ga e
tasuke-ta.
Taro-Nom
help-Past
‘Taro helped (her/him).’
b. e
Hanako-o tasuke-ta
Hanako-Acc help-Past
‘(She/He) helped Hanako.’

These sentences are acceptable only when the null arguments (the object in (85a) and the subject in (85b)) refer to the items registered (as topics) in a given discourse, as pointed out by Kuno (1973c). Due to the variable status of null arguments, an object of a complement sentence cannot be null if it refers to the matrix subject: 44

(86)
Hanakoi-ga [watasitati-ga e*i/j
tasuke-ru] to omot-ta.
Hanako-Nom we-Nom
help-Pres Comp think-Past
‘Hanakoi thought that we will help *heri/himj′.’

In (86), if the ec is in fact a variable, it cannot be locally A-bound by Hanako, the matrix subject, due to Condition C of Binding Theory. Once honorifics are involved, however, a null object that refers to the matrix subject is allowed:

(87)
Senseii-ga [watasitati-ga ei/j
o-tasuke-su-ru] to o-omoi ni nat-ta.
teacher-Nom we-Nom
help-Pres Comp HP-think-Hon-Past
‘The teacheri thought that we will help heri/himj′.’

The contrast here seems to suggest that the e that is not agreement-related is a variable and needs to be topic-bound, but the one that is agreement-related can be a pronominal and can refer to a matrix constituent, as any pronominal can.
Note in passing that the benefactive predicate can also license a null object in a complement sentence, as is shown in (88): 45

(88)
Hanakoi-ga [Taro-ga ei/j
tasukete-kure-ru] to omot-ta.
Hanako-Nom Taro-Nom
help-give-Pres Comp think-Past
‘Hanakoi thought that Taro will help heri/himj.’

If the benefactive predicates age-ru and kure-ru involve syntactic agreement, as was suggested above, the grammaticality of (88) can naturally be accounted for along with the grammaticality of (87). 46

subsection.heading: 5.2 Honorific concordance
subsection.p: With reference to sentences (53b) and (53c–e), we saw that what is responsible for honorific processes is not the presence of an item with SSS but rather the presence of the honorific form of a predicate. Because of this, it appears that honorific marking on predicates is optional and an SSS subject or object does not always give rise to honorific forms. Thus, as discussed in section 3.6, what matters is whether an SSS item is present when the predicate is of the honorific form, and not whether predicates are in the honorific form when an SSS item is present. This does not mean that the use of honorific forms is completely arbitrary, however. Observe the following data:

(89)
a. Sensei-ga *?aitu-o/ano kata-o o-home-ni nat-ta.
teacher-Nom the guy(Vul)-Acc/that person-Acc HP-drink-Hon-Past
‘The teacher praised that guy/that person.’
b. Taro-ga *go-hon-o/hon-o nakusi-yagat-ta.
-Nom HP-book-Acc/book-Acc loose-Vul-Past
‘Taro lost the book.’

What (89a) shows is that if the predicate is of the honorific form, other items in the sentence cannot be of the vulgar form. The opposite is also true, as (89b) shows: when the predicate is of the vulgar form, the honorific or polite form for the object noun is inappropriate. Thus, there seems to be some kind of honorific or politeness concordance among items in a sentence. This does not mean that concordance should always be strictly observed, however:

(90)
a. Sensei-wa go-zibun-o seme-ta.
teacher-Top HP-self-Acc blame-Past
‘The teacher blamed herself.’
b. Sensei-wa zibun-o o-seme-ni nat-ta.
c. Sensei-wa go-zibun-o o-seme-ni nat-ta.

(91)
a. Sensei-wa go-zibun-de o-kuruma-o araw-u.
teacher-Top HP-self-Acc HP-car-Acc wash-Pres
‘The teacher washes her car by herself.’
b. Sensei-wa zibun-de kuruma-o o-arai-ni-nar-u.
c. Sensei-wa go-zibun-de o-kuruma-o o-arai-ni-nar-u.

These sentences are honorifics, and they all express the speaker's respect for the subject sensei. Only in the (c) examples is the concordance observed, however. In the (a) examples, the predicates are of the plain form but the object and the adverb are of the honorific form. In the (b) examples, only the predicate is of the honorific form and other items are of the plain form. The situation here is basically the same as in (53b) and (53c–e) in section 3.6, where only one predicate is in the honorific form while the other is of the plain form, even though both predicates refer to the same SSS subject.

This fact may be considered in the following way. Suppose that the speaker's intention to indicate her respect for an SSS subject or object is a kind of operator over a sentence, and this operator requires at least one item in the sentence to be in the honorific form. If the sentence contains more than one item that is of the honorific form, the operator unselectively binds it, which in effects explains the partial concordance observed in the above. The ungrammatical cases in (89) are due to the conflict between the two such operators: the honorific operator and the vulgar operator cannot take place at the same time. 47

subsection.heading: 6 Conclusion
subsection.p: It was Harada (1976) who first extensively discussed the phenomena of honorifics in Japanese in generative grammar, considering SH and NSH to be agreement processes that involve the feature [SSS], socially superior to the speaker. Following this basic insight of his and referring to my more recent predecessors along the same lines (Suzuki 1989; Toribio 1990; Ura 1999), I have worked out in more detail how ‘agreement’ happens within the framework of checking theory. It is shown that the morphosyntactic characteristics of SH and NSH play an important role in accounting for exactly how agreement takes place. In particular, I have shown that the presence of an HP and the connective form of a predicate, which is characteristic of SH and NSH, is not just a mere indication of honorifics but is the key to the agreement between the honorific predicate and the SSS item, a subject for SH and a beneficiary non-subject for NSH.

This chapter started out with a rather detailed description of the morphology of Japanese honorifics. Such details have often been glossed over in syntactic studies on this phenomenon that pay attention mainly to the syntactic relation between the items relevant to this process, disregarding exactly what shape the honorific predicate exhibits. However, I have shown in later sections that the morphological details of the honorific predicate – such as the presence of an HP, the connective form of the predicate, the presence or absence of ni, and the existence of the predicate nar-u for SH and su-ru for NSH – are all crucial for a better understanding of how honorifics work in this language. For example, the existence of an HP is responsible for the ‘definite’ interpretation of the event expressed in SH and NSH, which incidentally explains why a noun with an HP is taken to be ‘definite’ if it is used in honorific context.

In addition to SH and NSH, I have examined the cases which behave similarly to these honorifics: rare-honorifics and the yagar-u construction, in relation to SH, and the age-ru ‘give’ benefactive construction, with regard to NSH. I have argued that the differences in morphological shape between SH and the above two cases are not accidental and that these are in fact different syntactic processes. The similarity results from the pragmatic uses of the constructions in question, not from their syntactic structures. As for NSH, I have shown that it and the age-ru construction exhibit strikingly similar behaviors, which are the very characteristics that are to be captured in NSH: the obligatory presence of a beneficiary and its structural position. I have suggested that NSH actually involves the predicate age-ru, which may show up as its humble (or NSH) form, sasiage-ru, or as its null counterpart.

Because it appears that honorific processes take place ‘optionally’, allowing a subject (or beneficiary non-subject) with [SSS] to occur without a honorific predicate, it has sometimes been claimed that they are not ‘agreement’ processes, which are characterized as being ‘mandatory’ and ‘one-to-one’ (cf. Namai 2000). If one considers that the occurrence of an [SSS] noun phrase ‘triggers’ honorification, which has been the view often assumed since Harada (1976), its application certainly looks ‘optional’, and the ‘one-to-many’ or ‘one-to-zero’ relations appear to be allowed. If the presence of an honorific form is taken to be responsible for requiring an item to ‘agree’ with it in terms of [SSS], however, the process can be regarded as ‘mandatory’ and ‘one-to-one’, meeting the characteristics of ‘agreement’. This is the view that this chapter specifically advocates.

subsection.heading: NOTES

p.span: 1 In what follows, we will not be concerned with pragmatic or semantic notions of ‘politeness’, nor will we get into the discussion on what constitutes ‘politeness in speech’. See Brown and Levinson (1987) for relevant discussion.
2 Though there are other languages, such as Korean, Tibetan, Javanese, etc. that have a grammatical system of honorifics, only Japanese is examined in this chapter.

3 The terms ‘Perfomative Honorifics’ (PH), ‘Subject Honorifics’ (SH), and ‘Object Honorifics’ (OH) are due to Harada (1976). Kuno (1987b) uses ‘Hearer Honorific’ (HH) instead of PH and ‘Non-Subject Honorific’ (NSH) for OH. In the traditional grammar of Japanese, PH or HH, SH, and OH or NSH are called teinei-go ‘polite forms’, sonkei-go ‘respect forms’, and kenzyoo-go ‘humble forms’, respectively. In the following discussion, I will follow Kuno's tgerminology; namely, HH, SH, and NSH, since it seems to express the phenomena more accurately than Harada's.

4 The affix -san that follows a person's name is a kind of courtesy title, similar to Mr., Ms., Miss or Mrs., but can be used for the second person as well, being equivalent to ‘you, Mr./Ms. Sato’. The use of -san is obligatory in plain and polite speech, but strange in vulgar speech, when referring to a second or third person adult. Those that are due special respect, such as teachers, doctors, lawyers, are customarily addressed and referred to with sensei ‘teacher, professor’ rather than -san. Neither -san nor sensei is used in reference to the speaker herself or members of her in-group when talking to her out-group members. See section 3.1 for relevant discussion, and note 13 for more on in-groups and out-groups.

subsection.p: The following abbreviations are used in glosses: Nom for the nominative case marker, -ga; Acc for the accusative case marker -o, Dat for the dative case marker -ni, Gen for the genitive case marker -no, Past for the past tense marker -ta/-da, Pres for the present tense marker -ru/-u (-ru after a consonant stem verb and -u for a vowel stem verb), Pass for the passive predicate, -rare (for a consonant stem verb)/-are (for a vowel stem verb), and Cop for the copulative predicate. For morphological items related to honorifics, HP is used for the polite prefix go-/o-, Hon for the SH form, Vul for the vulgar form.

p.span: 5 A reviewer of this chapter pointed out to me that Sells and Iida (1991) provide the following example where the referents of both the subject, sensei ‘the teacher’, and a non-subject, the indirect object Yamada-san ‘Mr./Ms. Yamada’, are supposed to be elevated with the use of the predicate that involves both SH and NSH forms. (With the use of masi-ta, the address is also respected.)

subsection.p:
(i)
Sensei-ga Yamada-san-ni hon-o o-sasiage-ni nari-masi-ta.
teacher-Nom Yamada-Dat book-Acc HP-give(NSH)-SH-polite-past
‘The teacher gave a book to Mr. Yamada.’

The grammaticality of this example, however, is quite dubious. Sells and Iida incidentally note that this type of construction is not possible for some speakers, a group to which I certainly belong. It seems to me that this type of sentence ‘derivatively’ results given the pragmatic need to express the respect for the referents of the subject and the object. However, as mentioned in the above, as far as the grammar is concerned, SH and NSH function in the opposite directions for expressing the speaker's respect – SH elevates the subject directly by making use of the SH form, while NSH elevates a non-subject by downgrading the subject – and the presence of the SH and NSH forms on a single predicate thus gives rise to a contradiction. Thus, I consider that sentences such as (i) are not allowed grammatically but may take place under certain pragmatic situations.

p.span: 6 The verb form used in honorifics is sometimes referred to as ‘infinitive’ or ‘gerundive’ in the literature. For example, Harada (1976) calls it ‘infinitive’ and Toribio (1990) takes it to be ‘gerundive’. However, the terms ‘gerundive’ and ‘infinitive’, are misleading, since it is hard to tell in Japanese what morphologically, semantically, or syntactically constitutes ‘infinitive’ or ‘gerundive’, and it does not seem too meaningful to argue whether some form is infinitive or gerundive without addressing this question. Verbs in Japanese conjugate in terms of various functions (present tense, perfect tense, conditional, volitional, etc.), and the form that appears in honorifics is traditionally called renyoo-kei ‘connective form’, the form that connects to another predicate. To avoid unnecessary confusions, I will use the term ‘connective form’ in the following to refer to the form of the verb that is used in honorifics. The term ‘gerundive’ is saved for phrases (not for a particular form of predicates) that are nominal in structure (i.e., DPs) and involve a VP inside.

subsection.p: The connective form is identical to the root form if the verb belongs to the class of vowel verbs (verbs whose stem ends with either /i/ or /e/). But if the verb belongs to the class of consonant verbs (verbs whose stem ends with a consonant), the connective form has the form of the stem with the vowel /i/. See McCawley (1968b) for the morpho-phonology of the conjugation system of Japanese predicates.

p.span: 7 There are quite a few suppletive SH forms for commonly used verbs (such as irassyar-u for ik-u ‘go’, omesiagari-ni nar-u for tabe-ru ‘eat’, goran-ni nar-u for mi-ru ‘see’, ossyar-u for i-u ‘say’, nasa-ru for su-ru ‘do’, etc.), which are to be learned item by item. Though some suppletive forms exhibit sub-regularities that may be of some interest to the morphosyntax of Japanese, I will not get into details here. See Harada (1976).

8 Though there are exceptions, the distribution of the honorific prefix (HP) o- and go- is mainly determined by the etymological characteristics of the item that they attach to; o- for native words and go- for Sino-Japanese words. Most loan words from European languages do not take any honorific prefix. The honorific prefixes o- and go- are not solely for predicates and they attach to adjectives and nouns. Some examples are given in (i). We will consider the honorific forms of Sino-Japanese (SJ) predicates in (11) and (12):

subsection.p:
(i)
Native verbs: yom-u o-yomi-ni nar-u ‘read’
SJ verbs: kenkyuu su-ru go-kenkyuu ni nar-u ‘research’
Native adjectives: utukusi-i o-utukusi-i ‘beautiful’
SJ adjectives rippa da go-rippa da ‘fine’
Native nouns: kao o-kao ‘face’
SJ nouns: kazoku go-kazoku ‘family’

p.span: 9 As will be discussed in section 3.6, there are some adjectives (and Sino-Japanese adjectives) that do not take an honorific prefix (HP), o- or go-:

subsection.p:
(i)
Adjectives: tadasi-i *o-tadasi-i ‘right’
hiku-i *o-hiku-i ‘low’
yawaraka-i *o-yawaraka-i ‘soft’
SJ adjectives: mutyuu-da *go/o-mutyuu-da ‘crazy about’
nigate-da *go/o-nigate-da ‘bad at’
yuumei-da *go/o-yuumei-da ‘famous’

For these adjectives, the form Adj-te/de-irassyaru, the connective form of an adjective followed by the suppletive honorific form of i(ru) ‘exist, be’, can optionally be employed, as in tadasiku-te irassyaru ‘right’, mutyuu-de irassyaru ‘crazy about’, etc.

p.span: 10 Just like SH forms, there are suppletive NSH forms such as itas-u for su-ru ‘do’, moos-u for i-u ‘say’, ukagaw-u for kik-u ‘ask’ or ik-u ‘go’, etc.
11 For characteristics of Sino-Japanese predicates, see Kageyama (1976, 1991, 1993), Grimshaw and Mester (1988), Hasegawa (1991), Terada (1990), Miyamoto (1997), Takahashi (2000), etc.

12 The presence of an HP does not always indicate honorifics. For some common nouns, such as o-hasi ‘chopsticks’, o-soba ‘noodles’, o-syooyu ‘soy sauce’, etc., the use of the HP o- is not particularly taken as a polite or honorific marker, but rather as a part of the words themselves. Without the HP o-, they may sound rough, especially in female speech. See section 3.4 for more discussion on the use of HP.

13 The concept of the speaker's ‘in-group’ and ‘out-group’ has to do with the social and psychological distance or closeness that the speaker feels toward other individuals around her. The speaker's close relatives, like parents and siblings, belong to her in-group, while strangers are considered to be out-group members. Whether one belongs to the speaker's in-group or out-group is relative and constantly shifts depending on conversational contexts. For example, the speaker's colleague can be an in-group member with respect to those who do not belong to their workplace (i.e., customers, employees of other companies, etc.) but she can be an out-group member with respect to the speaker's family members. In today's Japanese, close relatives are almost invariably considered to be ‘in-group’ members, as (19) suggests; however, the higher status of family members like parents or grandparents can be subject to honorification under formal situations and/or in the families of the upper class, where classical standards in the use of the language are preserved (or recommended).
14 NSH is possible in the context of (17c) and (i) is grammatical. NSH will be discussed in section 4 below:

subsection.p:
(i)
Gakusei-ga sensei-ni hon-o o-watasi-si-ta.
student-Nom teacher-Dat book-Acc HP-pass-NSH-Past
‘The student handed the book to the teacher.’

p.span: 15 In Harada's system, if the predicate is marked [Subject Honorific] via (19), the following transformations apply that give rise to appropriate SH forms: the honorific prefixation of an HP; the honorific infinitivization, which brings about the connective form; the particle -ni attachment to the connective form of the verb; the predicate nar-u-attachment; the Spell Out of an HP to either o- or go-, etc. The structure of the SH form will be discussed in sections 3.2, 3.3, and 3.4 below.

16 It is not quite clear in Toribio's analysis what triggers this Spec–Head agreement. She states: “it appears that predicates in Japanese can agree with the honorific feature of noun phrases, just as in some languages predicates agree with the person, number and gender features of their arguments” (1990: 537). “The subject also raises to SpecD where it triggers honorification through Spec–Head agreement, under the assumption that all specifiers and heads are involved in an agreement relationship which may be realized morphologically” (1990: 539). I do not provide a tree structure that shows Toribio's analysis here. We will discuss her system more closely in section 3.3, and the tree structure (35) below represents our analysis, which is a modified version of her analysis.

subsection.p: As will be discussed in section 3.6, to account for the optional realization of honorifics, it is necessary to consider that the honorific predicate requires the SSS subject but not the other way around.

p.span: 17 Not all the occurrences of connective forms take an HP. For example, sugi-ru ‘exceed’, as in (25a), cannot take an HP, unless it is part of an SH as in (25b). Thus, if the existence of an HP is an indication of [+N], the connective form must assume either [+N] or [−N], just as the -ing form of English may. See Harada (1976) and Kuno (1987b) for relevant discussion. See also the discussion concerning (30–33) below.

18 Though -ni in the SH predicate is often considered to be a case particle (as in Toribio 1990 and Suzuki 1989), the facts in (27–29) strongly suggest that it is a copula. To the extent that nominal adjectives (NAs) never occur independently without a copula, or with a case marker other than -ni, -ni that follows an NA seems most probably a copula. This in turn suggests that the -ni of the SH predicate may also be a copula.

19 However, there are minor differences between Suzuki's analysis and Toribio's: Suzuki considers nar-u to be a control verb, while Toribio analyzes it as a raising verb; in Suzuki's analysis, the [+N] status of gerunds lies in I, which consists of an HP and the gerundive morpheme -i, and agreement checking takes place between the head I and the subject in the Spec of IP, while in Toribio's analysis, it is D that gives rise to the [+N] status of the gerund and the head D has the nominalizing morpheme -i. When the subject is raised to the Spec of DP, Spec–Head agreement takes place, which triggers the attachment of an HP to V-i in the D head.

20 Nar-u occurs in the copulative construction and the predicate adjective/nominal adjective construction, which are exemplified below as well as in (32) and (33). Just like become in English, nar-u in these constructions is best analyzed as a raising predicate rather than a control predicate:

subsection.p:
(i)
Hanako-ga isya-ni nat-ta.
Hanako-Nom doctor-copula become-Past
‘Hanako became a doctor.’

(ii)
Ryoori-ga tumetaku nat-ta.
dish-Nom cold become-Past
‘The dishes became cold.’

(iii)
Gakuseitati-ga sizuka-ni nat-ta
students-Nom cold become-Past
‘The students became quiet.’

p.span: 21 As briefly mentioned in section 2 (note 12 in particular), some nouns ordinarily involve an HP without specifically marking honorifics (especially in female speech), as in o-soba ‘noodles’, o-sara ‘dish’, o-sake ‘sake’, etc. In such examples, the presence of an HP does not necessarily make the noun identifiable in the sense that is discussed in this section. The types of nouns that are particularly relevant to the discussion of this section include those that refer to body parts, such as kao ‘face’ and karada ‘body, health’; SJ activity nouns, such as kooen ‘lecture’, ryokoo ‘travel’, kenkyuu ‘research’; and picture nouns, like syasin ‘photo’, tegami ‘letter’.

22 That is, as briefly stated above, the HP on a noun not only helps identify its referent but specifies it in terms of its possessor, to whom the speaker's respect is due. As will be discussed in section 5.2, there is some kind of concordance among the occurrences of honorific expressions. Thus, when the noun is with an HP as in (37b), the predicate is expected to be in the form of honorifics, either SH or NSH, and the possessor of the noun is the target of the speaker's respect, which the predicate form indicates by making use of SH or NSH.

23 The indefinite use of go-hon in (37c) and (37d) may be acceptable in hyper-polite speech, where the presence of an HP on nouns simply marks the speech polite, as briefly mentioned in section 2. See note 21 above. Cf. Ide and McGloin (1990).

24 This does not mean that indefinite DPs cannot be a subject of SH predicates. As (i) shows, indefinite DPs are acceptable as long as they represent a class or a kind of people to whom respect is due:

subsection.p:
(i)
a. Misiranu sensei-ga hon-o o-kai-ni nat-ta.
unknown teacher-Nom book-Acc HP-buy-Hon-Past
‘Some teacher bought a book.’
b. Donataka-ga o-warai-ni nat-ta.
someone(Hon)-Nom HP-laugh-Hon-Past
‘Someone laughed.’

In (ia), the subject is a stranger but the speaker knows that whoever she may be, her social status is that of a teacher; therefore, respectable. Similarly, in (ib), the subject is someone not identifiable. But donataka ‘someone (honorific)’ is the honorific form of dareka ‘someone’, and the speaker knows that whoever she may be, she belongs to a class of people to be looked up to.

p.span: 25 In Hasegawa's system, the preposition by is inserted to give Case to an agent as the last resort when it cannot receive structural Case.

26 In Hasegawa's original analysis, whether the complement object receives Object Case is determined by whether the complement verb moves to -(r)are at (or before) S-structure or at LF. I assume (46a) here, since the same result obtains if -(r)are optionally absorbs Case.
27 See Hasegawa (1988) for details. See also Takezawa (1987) for ni Case.
28 (46) also accounts for indirect passives with an intransitive verb, exemplified in (i):

subsection.p:
(i)
Hanako-ga ame-ni hur-are-ta.
Hanako-Nom rain-Dat fall-Pass-Past
‘Hanako got rained on.’
The subject of -(r)are, the affectee of the complement event, moves to the Spec of TP to receive Nominative Case.

p.span: 29 Thus, Hasegawa's claim that Rare-SH, voluntary-(r)are, and Passive-(r)are are different manifestations of the same -(r)are accords with the historical developments of -(r)are; the most basic use of -(r)are is taken to be its voluntary use, from which the SH use and the passive use are derived. See Hashimoto (1969).

30 If the subject is phonologically present and appears with -ni as in (49b), the construction is most probably an instance of the zihatu ‘voluntary’ use of -(r)are. Marking the subject with -ni is characteristic of this construction.

31 As will be mentioned immediately below, yagar-u is used only in vulgar speech, and other expressions involved in sentences with yagar-u must equally be vulgar. Because of this requirement, (50) has vulgar pronoun forms, aitu instead of ordinary anata ‘you’, ore instead of watasi or boku ‘I’, which are neutral in terms of level of speech. See section 5.2 for discussion of politeness concordance among the items in a sentence.
32 As noted in section 3.4, a noun and its possessor agree, and when the possessor is an SSS, the noun may take an HP. See (41).

33 Given this state of affairs, there seem to be two ways to deal with NSH: (i) NSH is taken to be a syntactic process and the syntactic presence of the beneficiary (i.e., the item with SSS) is posited even if its presence is not too obvious; or (ii) NSH is a pragmatic process and the existence of a beneficiary is implied in the context but not necessarily in a syntactic structure. The second approach is suggested in Matsumoto (1997) and Mori (1993), among others; however, I would like to pursue the syntactic approach, (i), in the following discussion.

34 Harada (1976) notices that the trigger of NSH does not have to be an (indirect) object but can be ‘included’ in it. He speculates that there may be a hierarchy like the following that is responsible for determining the applicability of honorification:

subsection.p:
(i)
a. Subject
b. Indirect object
c. Direct object
d. ‘Non-terms’ of grammatical relation

p.span: 35 Thus, Toribio's account of the facts in (64f) is along the line of the Minimal Link Condition. In order to make her analysis go through, she needs to assume a version of the specified subject condition; that is, PRO, the subject argument, does not prevent the checking of the SSS feature of the (in)direct object.

36 In Japanese, Nominative ga can be multiply assigned. There are several ways to account for this fact. I assume that ga is given to a DP that is governed by Tense (i.e., at (inner or outer) Spec of TP, at outer Spec of VP whose head is stative) (cf. Hasegawa 1984; Tada 1992; Takezawa 1987). Nominative ga given to a subject, which is at inner Spec of TP, is one instance of this process.
37 Age-ru can be an independent predicate that means ‘give’:

subsection.p:
(i)
Hanako-ga Taro-ni hana-o age-ta.
Hanako-Nom Taro-Dat flower-Acc give-past
‘Hanako gave flowers to Taro.’

p.span: 38 The unmarked interpretation of (82) is, as has just been stated, to take Taro as a beneficiary; however, this is not the only interpretation; the beneficiary may not be Taro but an individual phonologically unexpressed but understood in the given discourse. That is, (82a) for example, may be interpreted as ‘Hanako helped Taro for someone implicit in the context.’ As will be discussed immediately below, I will present an analysis where age-ru involves a beneficial role which can be identical with an argument of the predicate to which age-ru attaches, or implicit (i.e., a null pronominal category) but identifiable from the discourse. See note 42 for relevant discussion.
39 If the action of ‘suing’ or ‘stealing’ is considered to be for the benefit of someone (who may be the object), (83) is allowed, a reading with which we are not concerned here.
40 If age-ru, not in its honorific form sasiage-ru, is used with NSH, the sentence is inappropriate:

subsection.p:
(i)
*Gakusei-ga sensei-o o-tasuke si-te age-ta.
student-Nom teacher-Acc HP-help-do-give-past
‘The students helped the teacher.’
As will be discussed in section 5, there must be some concordance ensured among the items in honorific sentences.

p.span: 41 Though the two versions of (84), either with sasiage-ru or without, have basically the same meaning and function, the version with sasiage-ru sounds more polite. This fact does not follow from the analysis here, however.

42 This is what Hasegawa (2000) presents as an analysis of the age-ru construction and NSH. In order to make this analysis go through, we have to allow an item to be doubly theta-marked; once inside the complement VP and the second time at the Spec of the benefactive predicate. Within the Government and Binding framework, the theta-criterion prohibits an item from receiving a theta-role multiple times. However, in view of the recent developments of the theory where a theta-role is identified by a particular syntactic position, it seems probable that we may pursue the direction where multiple theta-role assignment is allowed under certain circumstances (e.g., when a theta-assigning head requires feature checking), and the proposal here falls under such a case. (Cf. Hornstein 1999.)

43 Another possibility that is often assumed in Japanese syntax is to allow a null pronoun rather freely. Under this assumption, the interpretation and distribution of null pronouns are taken care of in pragmatics, not in formal grammar. Cf. Kameyama (1988) and Nakamura (1991).

44 When the complement subject is an empty category (ec), it can refer to the matrix constituent, as shown in (i), suggesting that it can be pronominal. In Huang's analysis, as long as Binding Condition B is observed, a null argument can be a pronominal and is co-indexed with the closest nominal element, the matrix subject in (i). In Hasegawa's analysis, PRO, a kind of pronominal, is allowed at the subject position. Thus, in either analysis, the null complement subject can be a variable or a pronominal but the null object can only be a variable, which is responsible for the contrast between (86) and (i):

subsection.p:
(i)
Taroi-ga [eci
Hanako-o tasuke-ru] to tikat-ta.
Taro-Nom
Hanako-Acc help-Pres Comp swear-Past
‘Taro swore that he will help Hanako.’

p.span: 45 Kure-ru, rather than age-ru, is used here. The meanings and functions of kure-ru and age-ru are the same, but the use of kure-ru indicates that the speaker's empathy is with the object of the sentence, while age-ru indicates it is with the subject. Since the speaker tends to have empathy with the subject in active sentences, the speaker's empathy is with Hanako, the subject of the matrix clause, in (88). The intended reading on the e is Hanako, which is the object of the complement sentence; hence, kure-ru must be used rather than age-ru (cf. Kuroda 1965; Kuno 1978a; Kuno and Kaburaki 1977 for relevant discussion).

46 It was Kuroda (1965) who first pointed out that the process of zero pronominalization (i.e., the interpretation of empty pronominals) is affected by the presence of benefactive predicates like age-ru and kure-ru; the same contrast seen in (86) and (88). As stated above, how empty pronominals are analyzed is a rather controversial issue in Japanese syntax, and it is beyond the scope of this chapter to settle this problem. Thus, the analysis presented here must be taken as a case study that attempts to capture the phenomena that involve both pronominals and honorifics (benefactive predicates) within the framework of Hasegawa (1984).
47 I owe to Jacquline Guéron (p.c.) the idea that the occurrence of honorifics may be due to some kind of politeness operator over a sentence.
